Unlike traditional media outlets and elsewhere in the “blogosphere” where the diversity of viewpoints is often reduced into partisan circles, IVN actively encourages writers and readers of differing political tendencies to engage in a constructive dialogue.” IVN presents information from a broad perspective and is well sourced. Leans slightly left, but not enough to be classified as such.

ire.org.name: Investigative Reporters and Editors
ire.org.notes: Investigative Reporters and Editors, Inc. (IRE) is a nonprofit organization that focuses on the quality of investigative reporting. Formed in 1975, it presents the IRE Awards and holds conferences and training classes for journalists. Its headquarters is in Columbia, Missouri, at the University of Missouri School of Journalism. The IRE Awards have categories in all different media (Wikipedia). IRE publishes some transparency news on their website that is bias free.

ibtimes.com.name: International Business Times
ibtimes.com.notes: The International Business Times is an online global business newspaper based in New York City, comprising 10 national editions and seven languages. The publication, sometimes called IBTimes or IBT, offers news, analysis and editorial commentary on business and business-related stories.  Offers news with minimal bias.

icij.org.name: International Consortium of Investigative Journalists
icij.org.notes: The International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) is a Washington-based international network launched in 1997 by the Center for Public Integrity which includes 165 investigative journalists in over 65 countries who work together on “issues such as “cross-border crime, corruption, and the accountability of power (Wikipedia).”

journals.cambridge.org.name: International Organization
journals.cambridge.org.notes: International Organization is a peer-reviewed academic journal that covers the entire field of international affairs.  It is published by the Cambridge University Press on behalf of the International Organization Foundation. According to the Journal Citation Reports, the journal has a 2014 impact factor of 3.019, ranking it 3rd out of 85 journals in the category “International Relations.”  Requires a paid subscription or pay per article download (Wikipedia).

freemedia.at.name: International Press Institute
freemedia.at.notes: International Press Institute (IPI) is a global organisation dedicated to the promotion and protection of press freedom and the improvement of journalism practices. Founded in October 1950, the IPI has members in over 120 countries.  The IPI is a member of the International Freedom of Expression Exchange, a global network of non-governmental organisations that monitors press freedom and free expression violations worldwide (Wikipedia).

rescue.org.name: International Rescue Committee (IRC)
rescue.org.notes: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) is a global humanitarian aid, relief and development nongovernmental organization. Founded in 1933 at the request of Albert Einstein, the IRC offers emergency aid and long-term assistance to refugees and those displaced by war, persecution or natural disaster. The IRC is currently working in over 40 countries and 22 U.S. cities where it resettles refugees and helps them become self-sufficient (Wikipedia). Does not use loaded language and is factually sourced.

janes.com.name: IHS Janes 360
janes.com.notes: Janes 360 comes from the Jane’s Information Group (often referred to as Jane’s) which is a British publishing company specializing in military, aerospace and transportation topics. Low biased informational reporting.

daily.jstor.org.name: JStor Daily
daily.jstor.org.notes: JStor Daily’s tagline is “Where News Meets Its Scholarly Match.”  This makes sense as the news articles written on this website are derived from the JStor digital library that consists of over 2000 academic journals.  They cover all topics including politics, but without the bias.

kff.org.name: Kaiser Family Foundation
kff.org.notes: The Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation (KFF), or just Kaiser Family Foundation, is an American non-profit organization, headquartered in Menlo Park, California. It focuses on major health care issues facing the nation, as well as U.S. role in global health policy. The Foundation states that it is a non-partisan source of facts and analysis, polling and journalism for policymakers, the media, the health care community, and the general public and kff.org is known for having the “most up-to-date and accurate information on health policy.” Through Kaiser Health News, KFF’s editorially independent news service dedicated to coverage of health care policy and politics, the Foundation provides coverage of health policy issues and developments at the federal and state levels in the health care marketplace and health care delivery system (Wikipedia). Kaiser is a low biased highly factual source for health care news and policy. This source could also be listed in the Pro-Science category.

maplight.org.name: Maplight
maplight.org.notes: MapLight is a nonpartisan, nonprofit research organization that reveals and tracks the influence of money in politics in the United States. The organization publishes a free public database linking money and politics data sources, including campaign contributions to politicians, how politicians vote on bills, and support and opposition to legislation. MapLight provides data on both campaign finance and voting behavior in one database. MapLight uses an in-house research team in addition to data sources that include the National Institute on Money in State Politics, the Center for Responsive Politics, and Govtrack. (Wikipedia)

mcclatchydc.com.name: McClatchyDC
mcclatchydc.com.notes: The McClatchy Company is a publicly traded American publishing company based in Sacramento, California. It operates 29 daily newspapers in 14 states.   McClatchy journalists have also won 9 Pulitzer prizes in their 159-year history (Wikipedia). Well sourced and has low bias.

en.mercopress.com.name: MercoPress
en.mercopress.com.notes: MercoPress is an online news agency based in Montevideo, Uruguay. The agency, founded in 1993, provides information focused on South America and the South Atlantic in general, with a particular emphasis on Mercosur member countries and covering the region’s insular territories. (Wikipedia) This source has low bias and reports factually with minimal loaded words.

metabunk.org.name: Metabunk
metabunk.org.notes: Metabunk is a forum group that validates or debunks conspiracies and exceptional claims.

nationaljournal.com.name: National Journal
nationaljournal.com.notes: National Journal is an American digital media company based in Washington, D.C., that covers the current political environment and emerging political and policy trends.  National Journal was first published in 1969 (Wikipedia). Offers straightforward journalism with minimal bias.

newamerica.org.name: New America
newamerica.org.notes: New America is a think tank and civic enterprise committed to renewing American politics, prosperity, and purpose in the Digital Age. Well sourced information with minimal bias.

newsela.com.name: Newsela
newsela.com.notes: Newsela is a data base of current events stories tailor-made for classroom use. Stories  are indexed by broad theme, that are both student-friendly and can be accessed in different formats by reading level. Newspaper writers rewrite a story four times for a total of five Lexile levels per story. Newsela’s content providers are the Washington Post, The Guardian, Scientific American and Tribune Content Agency.

newsnow.co.uk.name: NewsNow (UK)
newsnow.co.uk.notes: NewsNow is a news aggregator service that was launched in 1998.  NewsNow searches over 33,000 sources from all over the world in real time.  Like most news aggregators NewNow has minimal bias.  However, the sources they serve may have bias, therefore it is up to the consumer to determine the bias of each source.

nextavenue.org.name: Next Avenue
nextavenue.org.notes: Next Avenue is a digital platform launched by PBS that offers original and aggregated journalism aimed at baby boomers. Next Avenue is PBS’ first venture to begin on the Internet rather than on broadcast television (Wikipedia). Most news is geared to health, nutrition and political policy for aging baby boomer. Has minimal bias in reporting.

nextgov.com.name: NextGov
nextgov.com.notes: Nextgov is the all-day information resource for federal technology decision makers.  Bias is determined by the author, but for the most part they are pretty neutral.

novinite.com.name: Novinite
novinite.com.notes: Based in Bulgaria.  Has low biased reporting on American news and politics.

180report.com.name: OneEighty
180report.com.notes: OneEighty or 180Report.com is a news aggregation website that pulls news from a variety of sources.  The website has a button you can click to get news from right biased websites or left biased.  The sources they pull from are typically large known sources such as The Blaze or Huffington Post. While the content of the individual news sources are very biased, we are giving OneEighty the least biased designation because they are pulling news from both sides without commentary.

patheos.com.name: Patheos
patheos.com.notes: Patheos is a non-denominational, non-partisan online media company providing information and commentary from various religious and nonreligious perspectives.  With that said, Patheos is very hard to classify on a right-left perspective.  Patheos has 450 writers/bloggers covering 11 different religious categories including paganism and atheism.  Obviously there is a lot of opinion on this website, but because they cover all perspectives in one place we give them a least biased rating. However, any individual writer on this website may possess left, right bias or advocate for pseudoscience.  It is up to the reader to decide on the bias of each writer.

pgpf.org.name: Peterson Foundation
pgpf.org.notes: The Peterson Foundation has grants issued to other organizations regardless of political affiliation. Their primary focus is on fair and balanced budgets and the future of the US.  They stick to reporting facts and figures with opinion pieces mixed in on occasion. They have donated to Clinton, Bush, Heritage fund and several left leaning organizations making them very moderate in their views.  There’s little extremism as they talk of carbon tax & fair tax taking from both sides of the aisle.  They have an array of speakers from Bill Clinton to Alan Greenspan to Chris Christie.  Showing a bipartisan and moderate approach to fiscal policy and taxation. PETER G. PETERSON, for who the foundation is named after, served under Nixon and Clinton.  According to Wikipedia he has been quoted as saying; “I remain a Republican, but the Republicans have become a far more theological, faith-directed party, not troubling with evidence.” (M. Allen)

pewresearch.org.name: Pew Research
pewresearch.org.notes: Pew Research is a nonpartisan American think tank which is based in Washington, D.C. It provides information on social issues, public opinion, and demographic trends shaping the United States and the world. It also conducts public opinion polling, demographic research, media content analysis, and other empirical social science research. Pew Research Center does not take explicit policy positions (Wikipedia).

politifact.com.name: Politifact
politifact.com.notes: PolitiFact.com is a project operated by the Tampa Bay Times, in which reporters and editors from the Times and affiliated media outlets “fact-check statements by members of Congress, the White House, lobbyists and interest groups”.  They publish original statements and their evaluations on the PolitiFact.com website, and assign each a “Truth-O-Meter” rating. The ratings range from “True” for completely accurate statements to “Pants on Fire” (from the taunt “Liar, liar, pants on fire”) for false and ridiculous claims.  (Wikipedia) This is the gold standard for political fact checking.

polygraph.info.name: Polygraph.info
polygraph.info.notes: Polygraph.info is a fact-checking website produced by Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty  and Voice of America (VOA). The website serves as a resource for verifying the increasing volume of disinformation and misinformation being distributed and shared globally. Well sourced fact checker that is currently focused on Russian claims.

poynter.org.name: Poynter Institute
poynter.org.notes: The Poynter Institute for Media Studies is a non-profit school for journalism located in St. Petersburg, Florida. The school is the owner of The Tampa Bay Times newspaper. The school began on May 29, 1975.  This a low bias source with outstanding writing and journalism.  They also perform comprehensive Fact Checks.

pogo.org.name: Project on Government Oversight
pogo.org.notes: The Project On Government Oversight (POGO), founded in 1981, is an independent non-profit organization in the United States which investigates and seeks to expose corruption and other misconduct. POGO assists whistleblowers and investigates federal agencies, Congress, and government contractors.  This is a solid evidence based source.

publicpolicypolling.com.name: Public Policy Polling (PPP)
publicpolicypolling.com.notes: Public Policy Polling (PPP) is a U.S. Democratic polling firm based in Raleigh, North Carolina.  Political research firm YouGov found PPP’s gubernatorial polls to have the lowest average margin of error among national firms that polled in at least ﬁve gubernatorial races in the month preceding the election. In 2013 columnist Nate Cohn described PPP as a liberal pollster, although according to statistician Nate Silver, PPP had a tendency to slightly lean Republican as of September 2016. (Wikipedia)

prri.org.name: Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI)
prri.org.notes: The Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI) is an American nonprofit, nonpartisan research and education organization that conducts public opinion polls on a variety of different topics. PRRI is a public resource for journalists, scholars, policy makers and the general public. PRRI is a member of the National Council of Public Polls and is a founding member of the Transparency Initiative at the American Association of Public Opinion Research.  (Wikipedia)

parallax.news.name: Parallax News (PXW)
parallax.news.notes: This source asks a topical question and then presents 3 different perspectives from political figures or experts.  The people may be biased, but the presentation by the site is non-biased and informative.

news.cn.name: Reference News (Xinhua)
news.cn.notes: Daily newspaper from China that presents mostly unbiased reporting of international and USA news.

reporterslab.org.name: Reporters Lab
reporterslab.org.notes: The Reporters’ Lab explores new forms of journalism, including fact-checking, empowering democracies and holding governments accountable, and structured journalism, which creates new forms of storytelling and beat reporting. The Reporters’ Lab has minimal bias and is highly factual.

represent.us.name: Represent.Us
represent.us.notes: A website dedicated to ending corruption in politics.  Does have a slight left leaning bias, but generally factual in news and data.

reuters.com.name: Reuters
reuters.com.notes: A highly reputable news reporting service. Reuters has a policy of taking a “value-neutral approach.”  Reuters’ editorial policy states: “We are committed to reporting the facts and in all situations avoid the use of emotive terms. The only exception is when we are quoting someone directly or in indirect speech.”  (Wikipedia)  Reuters does not offer opinion and just reports news.

rollcall.com.name: Roll Call
rollcall.com.notes: Roll Call is a solid “just the facts” news source, featuring a writing staff with an impressive set of credentials in political journalism. The articles are well sourced, and the information is presented “as is” with very minimal bias. While looking through the articles one in particular caught my attention. The article addressed the much hyped, on both sides, possibility of using National Guard troops to assist ICE in finding and deporting illegal immigrants. There is no real substance to the claim at this point, which came from an early draft of a “what if” style memo that never reached any official level.  I’ve read numerous articles on the issue, and Roll Call’s article was the fairest and least biased I have seen.

sciencedebate.org.name: Science Debate
sciencedebate.org.notes: Science Debate is a website dedicated to getting politicians to discuss scientific issues.

scoopnest.com.name: Scoopnest
scoopnest.com.notes: Scoopnest is an online service that collects news “tweets” from a wide range of sources.  They also provide the ability to filter by topics such as politics or health, etc.  The Twitter sources it pulls from range from left to right and in the middle.  While this source does pull information from biased sources, Scoopnest itself is not providing commentary and remains neutral.  Hence we give Scoopnest a least biased rating for providing news from all sources.

snopes.com.name: Snopes
snopes.com.notes: Fact checking and myth debunking site.  Well sourced and accurate.

stripes.com.name: Stars and Stripes
stripes.com.notes: Stars and Stripes is an American military newspaper that focuses and reports on matters concerning the members of the United States Armed Forces. It operates from inside the Department of Defense, but is editorially separate from it, and its First Amendment protection is safeguarded by the United States Congress, to whom an independent ombudsman, who serves the readers’ interests, regularly reports *(Wikipedia). Stars and Stripes is balanced in reporting and is low in editorial bias. They source to credible information.

stimson.org.name: Stimson Center
stimson.org.notes: Founded in 1989, the Stimson Center is a nonprofit, nonpartisan think tank devoted to addressing transnational challenges in order to enhance global peace and economic prosperity.  Given 5-Star (Highly Transparent) rating by Transparify’s 2015 report.

stratfor.com.name: Stratfor
stratfor.com.notes: Stratfor is an American publisher and global intelligence company founded in 1996 in Austin, Texas, by George Friedman, who was the company’s chairman.  Stratfor is a well respected source for military intelligence.

sunlightfoundation.com.name: Sunlight Foundation
sunlightfoundation.com.notes: The Sunlight Foundation is an American 501(c)(3) nonpartisan, nonprofit organization that advocates for open government. The organization was founded in April 2006 with the goal of increasing transparency and accountability in the United States Congress, the executive branch, and in state and local governments. The foundation’s primary focus is the role of money in politics. The organization seeks to increase campaign finance regulations and disclosure requirements.  The Sunlight Foundation’s donors include the Open Society Foundations, The Pew Charitable Trusts, the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Ford Foundation, the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, the Omidyar Network, Bloomberg Philanthropies, and the Laura and John Arnold Foundation (Wikipedia).

texastribune.org.name: Texas Tribune
texastribune.org.notes: The Texas Tribune is a nonprofit media organization based in Austin, Texas. Its website and content in various delivery platforms serves as an alternative news source for Texas, with a goal of supplementing mainstream media sources. Low biased reporting.

thatsnonsense.com.name: That’s Nonsense
thatsnonsense.com.notes: That’s Nonsense is a resource for internet and social media scams and hoaxes.

chronicle.com.name: The Chronicle of Higher Education
chronicle.com.notes: The Chronicle of Higher Education is a newspaper and website that presents news, information, and jobs for college and university faculty and Student Affairs professionals (staff members and administrators). A subscription is required to read some articles (Wikipedia).

theconversation.com.name: The Conversation
theconversation.com.notes: The Conversation is an independent, not-for-profit media outlet that uses content sourced from the academic and research community. Present news with a centrist view point and relatively non-biased journalism.

thediplomat.com.name: The Diplomat Magazine
thediplomat.com.notes: The Diplomat is an online international news magazine covering politics, society, and culture in the Asia-Pacific region. It is based in Tokyo, Japan. Reporting with neutral wording and low bias.

economist.com.name: The Economist
economist.com.notes: The Economist is an English-language weekly news magazine owned by the Economist Group and edited in offices in London. Centrist views and straightforward non-biased reporting.  They carefully label opinion pieces.

thehumanist.com.name: The Humanist Magazine
thehumanist.com.notes: The Human Magazine is published by the American Humanist Association.  It is a Bi-monthly publication that covers everything from science and religion to media and technology to politics and popular culture.  Extremely well sourced and factual.  Leans slightly to the left politically.

indianexpress.com.name: The Indian Express
indianexpress.com.notes: The Indian Express is an English-language Indian daily newspaper. It is published in Mumbai by Indian Express Group.  Low biased coverage of the USA.

jpost.com.name: The Jerusalem Post
jpost.com.notes: The Jerusalem Post is a broadsheet newspaper based in Jerusalem, publishing only English and French editions.  Formerly regarded as left-wing, the paper underwent a noticeable shift to the right in the late 1980s.  From 2004, under then editor-in-chief David Horovitz, the paper took a more centrist position.  Is biased towards Israel, but very centrist in world affairs.

thejournal.ie.name: TheJournal.ie
thejournal.ie.notes: TheJournal.ie is an internet news publication in Ireland. It is a mixture of original and aggregated content.  Founded in 2010 and is a low bias source.

themarshallproject.org.name: The Marshall Project
themarshallproject.org.notes: The Marshall Project is a nonprofit nonpartisan online journalism organization focusing on issues related to criminal justice in the United States, led by former hedge fund manager Neil Barsky and former New York Times executive editor Bill Keller. (Wikipedia)

soas.ac.uk.name: The Middle East in London
soas.ac.uk.notes: The Middle East in London was started in 1974. The magazine is part of the London Middle East Institute and is published by the Institute on a bi-monthly basis.  Each issue is organised around a central theme related to the Middle East and North Africa (MENA), and the variety of themes is constantly growing (Wikipedia).

themoderatevoice.com.name: The Moderate Voice
themoderatevoice.com.notes: Centrist views, but does have opinion pieces that range from moderate left to right.

thenews.mx.name: The News (Mexico City)
thenews.mx.notes: Generally pulls news from the AP and Reuters.  Daily newspaper from Mexico City, Mexico.

outlook.monmouth.edu.name: The Outlook (Monmouth University)
outlook.monmouth.edu.notes: The Outlook is Monmouth University’s student run newspaper since 1933.  The reporting is relatively free of bias.

phnompenhpost.com.name: The Phnom Penh Post
phnompenhpost.com.notes: The Phnom Penh Post is a daily English-language newspaper published in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Founded in 1992 by publisher Michael Hayes and Kathleen O’Keefe, it is Cambodia’s oldest English-language newspaper. It is printed in full-color tabloid format. (Wikipedia)

theskimm.com.name: The Skimm
theskimm.com.notes: The Skimm is an email newsletter publisher launched in 2012.  The Skimm focuses on a short, simple, and easy-to-read version of the news, and is specifically targeted at urban women aged 22-34.  The stories are short and have little bias added.

timesofindia.indiatimes.com.name: Times of India
timesofindia.indiatimes.com.notes: Outstanding non-biased reporting on American and international news.

thewhim.com.name: The Whim
thewhim.com.notes: The Whim claims on their website: “We’d rather be second and accurate than be first and wrong. The Whim News Desk is a dedicated team of researchers and investigators committed to presenting the news without bias.” Our assessment reveals that The Whim is low biased and does not use loaded language. They stick to presenting facts about news stories and present both sides of issues.

thirdway.org.name: Third Way
thirdway.org.notes: Third Way is a Washington, D.C.-based public policy think tank founded in 2005. The think tank develops policy ideas, conducts public opinion research and hosts issue briefings. The organization has four policy divisions: Economics, National Security, Clean Energy, and Social Policy & Politics. Third Way develops and advocates for policies that it says represent the “vital center (Wikipedia).”

transparency.org.name: Transparency International
transparency.org.notes: Transparency International e.V. (TI) is an international non-governmental organization which is based in Berlin, Germany, and was founded in 1993. Its nonprofit purpose is to take action to combat corruption and prevent criminal activities arising from corruption. It publishes for example the Global Corruption Barometer and the Corruption Perceptions Index (Wikipedia). Offers low biased well source information on corruption.

turkeyandfacts.com.name: Turkey and Facts (Dogruluk Payi)
turkeyandfacts.com.notes: Turkey and Facts is the first fact checking website in Turkey.  The content comes from the Turkish language version at dogrulukpayi.com.  This is a well sourced fact check site.

tvw.org.name: TVW Washington State
tvw.org.notes: TVW is Washington’s public affairs network, providing gavel-to-gavel coverage of Washington State Legislature sessions and coverage of the Washington State Supreme Court and public affairs events. It is widely considered the model state level equivalent of C-SPAN (Wikipedia).

upi.com.name: United Press International (UPI)
upi.com.notes: United Press International (UPI) is an international news agency whose newswires, photo, news film, and audio services provided news material to thousands of newspapers, magazines and radio and television stations during the 20th century.  UPI is similar to Reuters and the AP, but on a smaller scale today.  Provides low biased news content.

usaspending.gov.name: USA Spending
usaspending.gov.notes: USAspending.gov is the publicly accessible, searchable website mandated by the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006 to give the American public access to information on how their tax dollars are spent.

usatoday.com.name: USA Today
usatoday.com.notes: USA Today is a national American daily middle-market newspaper published and owned by the Gannett Company.  It has the 3rd largest distribution rate in the United States.  They report news with minimal bias and a simple to read format for general audiences. May have a very slight left leaning editorial bias.

voanews.com.name: Voice of America
voanews.com.notes: Voice of America (VOA) is a United States government-funded multimedia news source and the official external broadcasting institution of the United States. VOA provides programming for broadcast on radio, TV, and the Internet outside of the U.S., in English and some foreign languages. (Wikipedia)

voiceofsandiego.org.name: Voice of San Diego
voiceofsandiego.org.notes: Voice of San Diego is a nonprofit news organization focused on issues affecting the San Diego region.  Provides neutral reporting that is factual and sourced.

votesmart.org.name: Vote Smart
votesmart.org.notes: Vote Smart, formerly called Project Vote Smart (PVS), is a non-profit, non-partisan research organization that collects and distributes information on candidates for public office in the United States. It covers candidates and elected officials in six basic areas: background information, issue positions (via the Political Courage Test), voting records, campaign finances, interest group ratings, and speeches and public statements.  Vote Smart does not accept contributions from corporations, labor unions, political parties, or other organizations that lobby, support or oppose candidates or issues.  (Wikipedia) This is a solid resource.

warontherocks.com.name: War on the Rocks
warontherocks.com.notes: War on the Rocks is a website that reports on national security, defense and military.  The articles are presented with minimal biased words, are credibly sourced and presented with minimal political bias.

wearethemighty.com.name: We Are The Mighty
wearethemighty.com.notes: We Are The Mighty provides news to military personnel. The content is news that is related to or impacts those who have served or are serving in the military.  The news is delivered with minimal bias.

wikipedia.org.name: Wikipedia
wikipedia.org.notes: Wikipedia is a free-content encyclopedia project based on an openly editable model.  Wikipedia’s articles provide links to guide the user to related pages with additional information.  Most content on Wikipedia is well sourced with minimal bias, however there are some entries that have not been vetted properly and need to be checked. Always look at the sources at the bottom of the page.

wilsoncenter.org.name: Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars
wilsoncenter.org.notes: The Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars (or Wilson Center), located in Washington, D.C., is a United States Presidential Memorial that was established as part of the Smithsonian Institution by an act of Congress in 1968. It is also a highly recognized think tank, ranked among the top ten in the world.

wn.com.name: World News
wn.com.notes: World News pulls news from a variety of sources, some of which might be biased.  Good resource to find news and explore further.

worldpoliticsreview.com.name: World Politics Review
worldpoliticsreview.com.notes: World Politics Review provides uncompromising analysis of critical global trends to give policymakers, analysts, academics and readers with a deep interest in international affairs the context they need to have the confidence they want. Provides low biased reporting that is factually sourced.

againstcronycapitalism.org.name: Against Crony Capitialism
againstcronycapitalism.org.notes: Works to expose crony capitalism.  Has a moderate right wing bias in reporting. Sometimes sources very biased, inaccurate sources.

americanactionforum.org.name: American Action Forum
americanactionforum.org.notes: The American Action Forum is a nonprofit issue advocacy group based in Washington, D.C. which promotes center right public policy. They promote innovative, free-market solutions to create a smaller, smarter government.  AAF sources their information to credible sources.

acsh.org.name: American Council on Science and Health
acsh.org.notes: This source is known to be funded by corporations and tends to lean toward anti-environment issues.  Though not scientifically wrong they exhibit a bias in favor of businesses.  From Wiki: The American Council on Science and Health (ACSH) is a controversial nonprofit (501(c)(3)) advocacy organization, founded in 1978 by Elizabeth Whelan, PhD. It describes itself as a “consumer education consortium” focusing on food, nutrition, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, lifestyle, the environment and health, but others have accused it of being biased in favor of industry.

afpc.org.name: American Foreign Policy Council
afpc.org.notes: Non-Profit dedicated to providing information about foreign policy.  Has a moderate right wing bias with Republican politicians on the board.

antiwar.com.name: Anti-War
antiwar.com.notes: Antiwar.com is a libertarian website which describes itself as devoted to “non-interventionism” and as opposing imperialism and war. It is a project of the Randolph Bourne Institute. Although the website has a right leaning bias in reporting it does feature many writers from across the political spectrum, including conservatives such as Pat Buchanan, libertarians such as Ron Paul, and leftists such as Noam Chomsky and Juan Cole (Wikipedia).

arabnews.com.name: Arab News
arabnews.com.notes: Arab News is an English-language daily newspaper published in Saudi Arabia. It is published simultaneously from Jeddah, Riyadh, and Dammam. The target audiences of the paper which is published in broadsheet are businessmen, executives and diplomats.

azcentral.com.name: Arizona Republic
azcentral.com.notes: The Arizona Republic is an American daily newspaper published in Phoenix. Circulated throughout Arizona, it is the state’s largest newspaper. Since 2000, it has been owned by the Gannett newspaper chain. (Wikipedia)

arkansasonline.com.name: Arkansas Democrat-Gazette
arkansasonline.com.notes: The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette is the newspaper of record in the U.S. state of Arkansas, printed in Little Rock with a northwest edition published in Lowell. It is distributed for sale in all 75 of Arkansas’ counties.

bostonherald.com.name: Boston Herald
bostonherald.com.notes: The Boston Herald is an American daily newspaper whose primary market is Boston, Massachusetts and its surrounding area. It was founded in 1846 and is one of the oldest daily newspapers in the United States. It has been awarded eight Pulitzer Prizes in its history.  The Boston Herald has a moderately conservative editorial department and typically endorses Republican candidates.

breakingdefense.com.name: Breaking Defense
breakingdefense.com.notes: Breaking Defense is an online defense magazine. They have a right-center political affiliation as they tend to support more authoritarian military use. However, they are well sourced and use minimal loaded words.

calgarysun.com.name: Calgary Sun
calgarysun.com.notes: The Calgary Sun is a daily tabloid newspaper published in Calgary, Alberta, Canada.  Has a moderate conservative editorial bias.

capoliticalreview.com.name: California Political Review
capoliticalreview.com.notes: The California Political Review is a website dedicated to California politics and especially spending and taxes. This source has a conservative political bias and is typically well sourced in presenting numbers and statistics.

cato.org.name: Cato Institute
cato.org.notes: The Cato Institute is an American libertarian think tank with a moderate right wing bias that is headquartered in Washington, D.C. It was founded as the Charles Koch Foundation in 1974 by Ed Crane, Murray Rothbard, and Charles Koch.  In July 1976, the name was changed to the Cato Institute.   The mission of the Cato Institute is to originate, disseminate, and increase understanding of public policies based on the principles of individual liberty, limited government, free markets, and peace.

c4ss.org.name: Center for a Stateless Society
c4ss.org.notes: The Center for a Stateless Society (C4SS) is an anarchist think-tank and media center. Its mission is to explain and defend the idea of vibrant social cooperation without aggression, oppression, or centralized authority.

christianitytoday.com.name: Christianity Today
christianitytoday.com.notes: Christianity Today magazine is an evangelical Christian periodical that was founded in 1956 and is based in Carol Stream, Illinois. The Washington Post calls Christianity Today, “evangelicalism’s flagship magazine (Wikipedia).” Christianity Today reports on news and politics with minimal emotional words and sources to credible information. Politically they have a moderate conservative bias as would be expected of Evangelical Christianity.

cincinnati.com.name: Cincinnati Enquirer
cincinnati.com.notes: Cincinnati daily newspaper. Is factual in reporting, has a right-center editorial bias.

gazette.com.name: Colorado Springs Gazette
gazette.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Colorado Springs, Colorado. Has a right-center editorial bias.

dispatch.com.name: Columbus Dispatch
dispatch.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Columbus, Ohio. Factual reporting with a right of center editorial bias.

commdiginews.com.name: Communities Digital News
commdiginews.com.notes: Was at one time a part of the Washington Times, but is now it’s own entity.  Has a similar right of center bias as the Washington Times.

cei.org.name: Competitive Enterprise Institute
cei.org.notes: The Competitive Enterprise Institute (CEI) is a non-profit, libertarian think tank in the United States. Founded by Fred L. Smith, Jr., on March 9, 1984, in Washington, D.C., it seeks to advance economic liberty by fighting excessive government regulation because it believes that a free marketplace that allows entrepreneurship and innovation to thrive is better policy. (Wikipedia) This source has a horrible record when dealing with consensus science and has a pro-libertarian bias.

cfr.org.name: Council on Foreign Relations
cfr.org.notes: The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR), founded in 1921, is a United States 4900-member organization, nonprofit, publisher, and think tank specializing in U.S. foreign policy and international affairs (Wikipedia). Has a right-center bias in reporting.

telegraph.co.uk.name: Daily Telegraph
telegraph.co.uk.notes: The Daily Telegraph is a broadsheet newspaper published in London by Telegraph Media Group and distributed across the United Kingdom and internationally. The Daily Telegraph has been politically conservative in modern times (Wikipedia).

dallasnews.com.name: Dallas Morning News
dallasnews.com.notes: The Dallas Morning News is a daily newspaper serving the Dallas–Fort Worth area of Texas.  Has a right of center editorial bias throughout its long history.

desmoinesregister.com.name: The Des Moines Register
desmoinesregister.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Iowa. The Des Moines Register is factual in reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

deseretnews.com.name: Deseret News
deseretnews.com.notes: The Deseret News is a newspaper published in Salt Lake City, Utah, United States. It is Utah’s oldest continuously published daily newspaper and has the largest Sunday circulation in the state and the second largest daily circulation behind The Salt Lake Tribune. The editorial tone of the Deseret News is usually described as moderate to conservative, and is often assumed to reflect the values of its owner, the Church of Latter Day Saints. For example, the newspaper does not accept advertising that violates church standards (Wikipedia).

desertsun.com.name: Desert Sun
desertsun.com.notes: The Desert Sun is a local daily newspaper serving Palm Springs and the surrounding Coachella Valley in Southern California. Factual reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

detroitnews.com.name: Detroit News
detroitnews.com.notes: The Detroit News is a daily newspaper from Detroit, Michigan.  Has a right-center editorial bias.

edmontonsun.com.name: Edmonton Sun
edmontonsun.com.notes: The Edmonton Sun is a daily tabloid newspaper and news website published in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. Factual Reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

jacksonville.com.name: Florida Times-Union
jacksonville.com.notes: The Florida Times-Union is a major daily newspaper in Jacksonville, Florida, USA. Widely known as the oldest newspaper in the state, it began publication as the Florida Union in 1864 (Wikipedia). Has a right-center editorial bias.

forbes.com.name: Forbes
forbes.com.notes: Forbes is an American business magazine. Published bi-weekly, it features original articles on finance, industry, investing, and marketing topics. Forbes also reports on related subjects such as technology, communications, science, and law.

foreignpolicyi.org.name: Foreign Policy Initiative
foreignpolicyi.org.notes: The Foreign Policy Initiative (FPI) is an American think tank. According to its website, the FPI is committed to robust support for democratic allies, human rights, a strong American military equipped to meet the challenges of the 21st century, and strengthening America’s global economic competitiveness (Wikipedia). FPI is aligned right of center politically through is use of military and is factually sourced.

fpri.org.name: Foreign Policy Research Institute
fpri.org.notes: The Foreign Policy Research Institute (FPRI) is an American think tank based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.  The Institute conducts research on geopolitics, international relations, and international security in the various regions of the world as well as on ethnic conflict, U.S. national security, terrorism, and on think tanks themselves (Wikipedia). Has a right of center political bias in reporting.

fortune.com.name: Fortune Magazine
fortune.com.notes: Fortune is a multinational business magazine, published and owned by Time Inc. and headquartered in New York City. The publication was founded by Henry Luce in 1929. The magazine competes with Forbes and Bloomberg Businessweek in the national business magazine category (Wikipedia).

fee.org.name: Foundation for Economic Education
fee.org.notes: Non-profit organization in teaching the principles of a free society with a right of center bias since its founding in 1946.

franklincenterhq.org.name: Franklin Center for Government and Public Integrity
franklincenterhq.org.notes: The Franklin Center for Government and Public Integrity is an online nonprofit news organization in the United States that publishes news and commentary from a free market, limited government perspective on state and local politics. The Franklin Center publishes Watchdog.org, a network of state-based websites (Wikipedia). According to Sourcewatch the Franklin Center has a right wing position on climate change and has been criticized for rejecting the consensus of science. This source is also funded by corporations from the fossil fuel industries.

freedomhouse.org.name: Freedom House
freedomhouse.org.notes: Freedom House is a U.S.-based nonpartisan 501(c)(3) U.S. Government funded non-governmental organisation (NGO) that conducts research and advocacy on democracy, political freedom, and human rights. Freedom House was founded in October 1941. Freedom House has been criticized for excessively criticizing states opposed to US interests while being unduly sympathetic to regimes supportive of US interests (Wikipedia).

mlive.com.name: Grand Rapids Press
mlive.com.notes: The Grand Rapids Press is a daily newspaper published in Grand Rapids, Michigan.  Typically endorses Republican candidates and a right-center editorial bias.

group30.org.name: Group of Thirty
group30.org.notes: The Group of Thirty, often abbreviated to G30, is an international body of leading financiers and academics which aims to deepen understanding of economic and financial issues and to examine consequences of decisions made in the public and private sectors related to these issues. Topical areas within the interest of the group include: the foreign exchange market, international capital markets, international financial institutions, central banks and their supervision of financial services and markets, and macroeconomic issues such as product and labor markets (Wikipedia). Has a right leaning economic bias toward free market capitalism.

gulfnews.com.name: Gulf News
gulfnews.com.notes: Gulf News is a daily English language newspaper published from Dubai. The Gulf News has a pro-Dubai bias and also has anti-Israel views. Reports USA news with a right of center reporting bias.

heraldsun.com.au.name: Herald-Sun
heraldsun.com.au.notes: The Herald Sun is a morning tabloid newspaper based in Melbourne, Australia. It is published by The Herald and Weekly Times, a subsidiary of News Corp Australia, itself a subsidiary of News Corp. (Wikipedia)

hpenews.com.name: High Point Enterprise
hpenews.com.notes: Daily newspaper from High Point North Carolina. Is factual in reporting, but has a right-Center editorial bias.

thehindubusinessline.com.name: The Hindu Business Line
thehindubusinessline.com.notes: Business Line or The Hindu Business Line is an Indian business newspaper published by Kasturi & Sons, the publishers of the newspaper The Hindu located in Chennai, India. Is primarily a financial media outlet with a slight right economic bias.

honestreporting.com.name: Honest Reporting
honestreporting.com.notes: HonestReporting (or Honest Reporting) is a pro-Israel, non-governmental organization that monitors the media for what it perceives as bias against Israel. The organization is a United States 501(c)3 registered charity headquartered in Skokie, Illinois, with its editorial staff based in Jerusalem, Israel. It has affiliates in the United States, UK, Canada, Italy, and Brazil (Wikipedia).

hoover.org.name: Hoover Institution
hoover.org.notes: The Hoover Institution is an American public policy think tank and research institution located at Stanford University in California. The Hoover Institution has a right-center bias in reporting and political affiliation. They also have published some articles that do not support the consensus of science.

humanprogress.org.name: Human Progress
humanprogress.org.notes: Human Progress attempts to show how capitalism and free markets have led to progress for humanity.  HumanProgress.org is a project of the Cato Institute and has corporate funding. Has right-center bias in reporting and sometimes promotes pseudoscience.

theihs.org.name: Institute for Humane Studies
theihs.org.notes: The Institute for Humane Studies (IHS) is a libertarian non-profit organization that engages with students and professors throughout the United States to encourage the study and advancement of freedom. IHS has received funding from a number of foundations, including the Sarah Scaife Foundation, the John Templeton Foundation, the F.M. Kirby Foundation, the Marcus Foundation, the John William Pope Foundation, the Ed Uihlein Family Foundation, the Ralph Smeed Private Memorial Foundation, the Koch Family Foundations, the Searle Freedom Trust, the E.L. Craig Foundation, and the Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation (Wikipedia). This source reports factually and is sourced properly. Has a Right-Center political affiliation.

investors.com.name: Investors Business Daily
investors.com.notes: Investor’s Business Daily (IBD) is an American media company covering international business, finance, economics and the stock market.   IBD allows lobbyists and PR reps for right wing think tanks like the Heartland Institute and the Competitive Enterprise Institute to write pseudo-scientific propaganda.

independent.ie.name: Irish Independent
independent.ie.notes: The Irish Independent is the flagship publication of Independent News & Media (INM) and Ireland’s largest-selling daily newspaper. Is factual in reporting news, but has a populist conservative editorial bias.

israelhayom.com.name: Israel Hayom
israelhayom.com.notes: Israel Hayom (Israel Today) is an Israeli national Hebrew language free daily newspaper, first published in 2007. It has the largest daily circulation in the country.  Has a very strong Netanyahu bias and right-center political bias in reporting.

itv.com.name: ITV News
itv.com.notes: ITV News is the branding of news programmes on the British television network ITV. ITV News has the second-largest television news audience in the United Kingdom, second only to BBC News. ITV has a slight right-center bias in reporting.

reviewjournal.com.name: Las Vegas Review Journal
reviewjournal.com.notes: The Las Vegas Review-Journal is a major daily newspaper published in Las Vegas, Nevada since 1909. It is the largest circulating daily newspaper in Nevada, and one of two daily newspapers in the Las Vegas area. The paper usually takes what is perceived to be a libertarian editorial stance.

learnliberty.org.name: Learn Liberty
learnliberty.org.notes: In 2010, the Institute for Humane Studies launched LearnLiberty.org, a website producing educational videos on libertarian ideas. The site’s stated goals are “to provide a starting point for conversations on important questions: What is the nature of man and society? What are the best ways to organize human society? What is the proper role for government (Wikipedia)?” Reports with a right-center bias in story selection and political affiliation. Sources to credible information.

lexingtoninstitute.org.name: Lexington Institute
lexingtoninstitute.org.notes: The goal of the Lexington Institute to inform, educate, and shape the public debate of national priorities in those areas that are of surpassing importance to the future success of democracy, such as national security, education reform, tax reform, immigration and federal policy concerning science and technology (

lfpress.com.name: London Free Press
lfpress.com.notes: The London Free Press is a daily newspaper based in London, Ontario, Canada. It has the largest circulation of any newspaper in Southwestern Ontario (Wikipedia). Reports factually and with proper sources. Has a right of center editorial bias.

mackinac.org.name: Mackinac Center for Public Policy
mackinac.org.notes: The Mackinac Center for Public Policy is an American non-profit free market think tank headquartered in Midland, Michigan. It is the largest state-based free market think tank in the United States (Wikipedia).

macleans.ca.name: Maclean’s Magazine
macleans.ca.notes: Maclean’s is a Canadian weekly news magazine that was founded in 1905, reporting on Canadian issues such as politics, pop culture, and current events. Has right of center bias in reporting and wording, but well sourced and factual.

manhattan-institute.org.name: Manhattan Institute for Policy Research
manhattan-institute.org.notes: The Manhattan Institute for Policy Research is an American think tank established in New York City in 1978 by Antony Fisher and William J. Casey.  The primary focus is on economics and law enforcement. Has a right-center bias in reporting and affiliation.

militarytimes.com.name: Military Times
militarytimes.com.notes: The Military Times publishes news related to the military and defense.  This source’s target audience is current and former military personnel. Has a right-center political bias in reporting.

mises.org.name: Mises Daily
mises.org.notes: The Ludwig von Mises Institute (LvMI), often referred to as the Mises Institute, is a tax-exempt organization located in Auburn, Alabama, United States. It is named after Austrian School economist Ludwig von Mises (1881–1973). Its website states that it exists to promote “teaching and research in the Austrian school of economics, and individual freedom, honest history, and international peace, in the tradition of Ludwig von Mises and Murray N. Rothbard (Wikipedia).” The Mises Daily produces news that has a right wing economic bias and sometimes sources to other highly biased right wing sources. Does not always support the consensus of science.

nakedcapitalism.com.name: Naked Capitalism
nakedcapitalism.com.notes: Naked Capitalism is an American financial news and analysis blog that “chronicles the large scale, concerted campaign to reduce the bargaining power and pay of ordinary workers relative to investors and elite technocrats (Wikipedia).” Naked Capitalism is well sourced and does not use many loaded words. Holds a right of center political fiscal view.

nationalinterest.org.name: National Interest
nationalinterest.org.notes: The National Interest (TNI) is an American bi-monthly international affairs magazine published by the Center for the National Interest. It is associated with the realist school of foreign policy thought.  This is a strong source for foreign affairs with mostly balanced reporting.

nationalpost.com.name: National Post
nationalpost.com.notes: The National Post is a Canadian English-language newspaper.  This paper has a conservative bias, but is responsible in reporting, therefore we give it a Right-Center bias due to quality reporting.

nypost.com.name: New York Post
nypost.com.notes: A daily tabloid type newspaper from New York City.  This source can swing very far to the right, but does occasionally provide a balanced account.  Not a very credible source overall.

newsheist.com.name: News Heist
newsheist.com.notes: News Heist is a news curation website that does not produce any original content.  All news links go to external sources.  In reviewing several news links, they went to a variety of left and right sources, some also went to Zero Hedge, which we classify as a conspiracy website. The selected news stories tend to lean to the right.  We give this source a mixed factual rating because of links to a known conspiracy site.  Further, this source does not have an about page, disclaimer or any other information about their purpose or ownership.

newsrescue.com.name: News Rescue
newsrescue.com.notes: News Rescue is a Nigerian news and opinion website with a right-center bias. Unfortunately, this source does not have an “about” page, so it is difficult to understand their mission. In reviewing articles this source uses minimal loaded words, but does tend to favor stories that are right of center. Stories are sourced appropriately.

oilprice.com.name: Oil Price
oilprice.com.notes: Oilprice.com provides updated Oil and energy prices. They also have information and articles written by journalists and analysts in the Energy, Political and Economic space.  Has a right of center view.

omaha.com.name: Omaha World-Herald
omaha.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Omaha, Nebraska. Is factual reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

ocregister.com.name: Orange County Register
ocregister.com.notes: Right of center daily newspaper from Orange County California.

oregonlive.com.name: Oregonian
oregonlive.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Portland, Oregon. Is factual in reporting with right-center editorial bias.

orlandosentinel.com.name: Orlando Sentinel
orlandosentinel.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Orlando, Florida with a right-center editorial bias.

pacificresearch.org.name: Pacific Research Institute
pacificresearch.org.notes: The Pacific Research Institute for Public Policy (PRI) is a California-based free-market think tank which promotes “the principles of individual freedom and personal responsibility” through policies that emphasize a free economy, private initiative, and limited government. PRI was founded in 1979 by British philanthropist Antony Fisher (Wikipedia)

peninsuladailynews.com.name: Peninsula Daily News
peninsuladailynews.com.notes: The Peninsula Daily News is a daily newspaper printed Sundays through Fridays, covering the northern Olympic Peninsula in the state of Washington, United States.  They have a slight right of center bias on reporting and editorials.

triblive.com.name: Pittsburgh Tribune Review
triblive.com.notes: The Pittsburgh Tribune Reviews is a daily newspaper from Pittsburgh Pennsylvania. They are factual in reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

policyed.org.name: PolicyEd
policyed.org.notes: Policyed.org is a website that is affiliated with the Hoover Institution that covers US policy and promotes free market capitalism. They generally report with minimal loaded words and good sourcing. They have a right wing political affiliation.

publicinterestlegal.org.name: Public Interest Legal Foundation
publicinterestlegal.org.notes: Founded in 2012, PILF is a 501(c)(3) public interest law firm dedicated entirely to election integrity. The Foundation exists to assist states and others to aid the cause of election integrity and fight against lawlessness in American elections. Drawing on numerous experts in the field, the Foundation seeks to protect the right to vote and preserve the Constitutional framework of American elections.

punchingbagpost.com.name: PunchingBag Post
punchingbagpost.com.notes: PunchingBag Post has the tagline “A Conservative Perspective.”  Although they clearly reveal their bias, they really do not overtly show it in reporting.  Most headlines match the content of news articles, it has decent sourcing, and only moderately favors right wing stories.

realcleardefense.com.name: Real Clear Defense
realcleardefense.com.notes: A division of Real Clear Politics that focuses on military issues.

realclearinvestigations.com.name: Real Clear Investigations
realclearinvestigations.com.notes: A division of Real Clear Politics that focuses on investigations.

realclearpolitics.com.name: Real Clear Politics
realclearpolitics.com.notes: Primary reports on political polls, but does have news articles with a right-center bias.

reason.com.name: Reason
reason.com.notes: Reason is an American libertarian monthly magazine published by the Reason Foundation. The magazine has a circulation of around 50,000 and was named one of the 50 best magazines in 2003 and 2004 by the Chicago Tribune. Is generally factual and sourced properly with a right-center reporting bias.

valleynewslive.com.name: Red River Valley News
valleynewslive.com.notes: Red River Valley News broadcasts on KVLY 17 hours of news per week, with 4 1/2 hours on weekdays and 1 1/2 on the weekends between the main NBC channel and the CBS-affiliated KXJB-LD.  They claim to lead the news market in Fargo, North Dakota. Has a right-center editorial bias.

cato.org/regulation.name: Regulation Magazine
cato.org/regulation.notes: Regulation is a quarterly periodical about policy published by the Cato Institute. It was started as a bimonthly magazine in 1977 by the American Enterprise Institute and acquired by Cato in 1989. Past editors have included former Supreme Court justice Antonin Scalia, Murray Weidenbaum, Christopher DeMuth,Walter Olson, and Peter Huber. Peter Van Doren has edited the magazine since 1999 (Wikipedia). Sometimes sources to biased information.

richmond.com.name: Richmond Times-Dispatch
richmond.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Richmond, Virginia with a right-center editorial bias.

rt.com.name: RT News
rt.com.notes: RT, originally Russia Today, is a television network funded by the Russian government. It operates cable and satellite television channels directed to audiences outside of Russia as well as providing Internet content in various languages, including Russian (Wikipedia). It has right of center coverage of the USA.  Highly biased toward Russia and occasionally runs conspiracy stories.

russia-insider.com.name: Russia Insider
russia-insider.com.notes: Russia Insider is a news website launched in September 2014, based in Moscow, Russia. Russia Insider reports on political and social affairs and aims to provide an alternative view to the mainstream news about Russia and country-related issues. Its mission is media criticism and reform, underlining the issues of Western media which are seen by the founders as extremely biased, especially on Russia. The website was criticized for its pro-Russian stance, considered to be alongside several highly visible partisan outlets such as RT, Ruptly and Sputnik (Wikipedia). Has a right-center bias in reporting and sometimes sources to questionable media outlets such as Infowars.

tass.com.name: Russian News Agency-TASS
tass.com.notes: Russian News Agency TASS  is a major news agency in Russia, founded in 1902. Tass is the largest Russian news agency, and the fourth largest in the world after Reuters, the Associated Press (AP) and Agence France-Presse (AFP). Tass is owned by the Government of Russia (Wikipedia). TASS has a very strong pro-Russian bias, especially as it relates to news regarding the Ukraine. When reporting non-Russian news they report with minimal loaded words and factually source their information. Editorially, they have just a right of center bias.

srnnews.com.name: Salem Radio Network News (SRN News)
srnnews.com.notes: Salem Radio Network News is owned by the Salem Radio Network. The SRN News website features news and opinion reports that are very well sourced, neutral in language and factual. The editorial position of SRN News is conservative, with conservative radio hosts Michael Medved, Hugh Hewitt and Dennis Prager providing content.

sandiegouniontribune.com.name: San Diego Union Tribune
sandiegouniontribune.com.notes: The San Diego Union-Tribune is an American metropolitan daily newspaper, published in San Diego, California. They are factual in reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

sun-sentinel.com.name: South Florida Sun-Sentinel
sun-sentinel.com.notes: The Sun-Sentinel is the main daily newspaper of Broward County, Florida. Owned by Tronc, it circulates all throughout the three counties that comprise South Florida. It is the largest-circulation newspaper in the area (Wikipedia). Has a right-center editorial bias.

spokesman.com.name: The Spokesman-Review
spokesman.com.notes: The Spokesman-Review is a daily broadsheet newspaper based in Spokane in U.S. state of Washington, where it is the city’s only daily publication.

sputniknews.com.name: Sputnik News
sputniknews.com.notes: Russian news media company out of Moscow.  Is pro-Russian government and favors Republicans in the USA.  Has been known to publish conspiracies.  Take them with a grain of salt.

star-telegram.com.name: Star Telegram
star-telegram.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Fort Worth, Texas with a right-center editorial bias.

statesmanjournal.com.name: Statesman Journal
statesmanjournal.com.notes: A right of center subsidiary of USA Today.

strategic-culture.org.name: Strategic Culture Foundation
strategic-culture.org.notes: According to their website the Strategic Culture Foundation provides a platform for exclusive analysis, research and policy comment on Eurasian and global affairs. This source has a very strong pro-Russian bias, however they do source their information well.

tallahassee.com.name: Tallahassee Democrat
tallahassee.com.notes: The Tallahassee Democrat is a daily broadsheet newspaper. It covers the area centered on Tallahassee in Leon County, Florida, as well as adjacent Gadsden County, Jefferson County, and Wakulla County. The newspaper is owned by Gannett Co., Inc (Wikipedia). Presents news factually, with strong sources and with minimal bias. Has a conservative editorial board.

tbo.com.name: Tampa Tribune
tbo.com.notes: The Tampa Tribune was an online newspaper published in Tampa, Florida.  Has a consistent right wing editorial stance.  Endorses Republican candidates.

taxfoundation.org.name: Tax Foundation
taxfoundation.org.notes: The Tax Foundation is an independent Washington, D.C.-based think tank, founded in 1937, that collects data and publishes research studies on U.S. tax policies at both the federal and state levels.  It describes itself as an “independent tax policy research organization” (Wikipedia). They are cited in the media as a nonpartisan or bipartisan organization, and are also described as business-friendly or conservative. Well sourced information.

tharawat-magazine.com.name: Tharawat Magazine
tharawat-magazine.com.notes: Tharawat Magazine is a business and financial magazine.  Has a slight rightward bias, but it is minimal.

algemeiner.com.name: The Algemeiner Journal
algemeiner.com.notes: The Algemeiner Journal is a New York-based newspaper, covering American and international Jewish and Israel-related news. Is typically well sourced with a right-center editorial bias.

theamericanconservative.com.name: The American Conservative
theamericanconservative.com.notes: The American Conservative (TAC) is a bi-monthly journal of opinion published by the American Ideas Institute. It has argued against American interventionism, against a debt-based fiscal policy, and against the intrusions on Americans’ private lives by the institutions and mores that exist and the wisdom that underlies them. (Wikipedia) Very well written source with a libertarian perspective.

the-american-interest.com.name: The American Interest
the-american-interest.com.notes: The American Interest (AI) is a bimonthly magazine focusing primarily on foreign policy, international affairs, global economics, and military matters.  Excellent journalism with a slight right of center bias.

theaustralian.com.au.name: The Australian
theaustralian.com.au.notes: The Australian is a broadsheet newspaper published in Australia from Monday to Saturday each week since 14 July 1964.  It is the biggest-selling national newspaper in the country. Has a right-center editorial bias.

thefiscaltimes.com.name: The Fiscal Times
thefiscaltimes.com.notes: The Fiscal Times has a right of center economic bias.  Well sourced and factual in reporting.

independent.org.name: The Independent Review
independent.org.notes: Is a non-profit, non-partisan, scholarly research and educational organization that sponsors in-depth studies of critical social and economic issues. Has a right wing political bias in reporting, but is well sourced with credible information.

jamestown.org.name: The Jamestown Foundation
jamestown.org.notes: Their mission is to inform and educate policy makers and the broader community about events and trends in those societies which are strategically or tactically important to the United States and which frequently restrict access to such information. Has a strong pro-military bias.

the-japan-news.com.name: The Japan News
the-japan-news.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Japan with a right-center editorial bias as it relates to western news.

thelibertarianrepublic.com.name: The Libertarian Republic
thelibertarianrepublic.com.notes: The Libertarian Republic is a free market news, culture, and opinion magazine featuring the writing of prominent libertarians, conservatives, independents and sometimes democrats. The goal of TLR is to inform and educate citizens on important news stories from a perspective of economic freedom and personal liberty.

thenational.ae.name: The National (UAE)
thenational.ae.notes: The National is a government-owned English-language daily newspaper published in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.  Very pro-government, but is relatively unbiased in reporting news from around the world.

oklahoman.com.name: The Oklahoman
oklahoman.com.notes: Daily Newspaper from Oklahoma with a right-center editorial bias.

pe.com.name: The Press-Enterprise
pe.com.notes: The Press-Enterprise is a paid daily newspaper published by Digital First Media that serves the Inland Empire in Southern California. Headquartered in downtown Riverside, California, it is the primary newspaper for Riverside County, with heavy penetration into neighboring San Bernardino County (Wikipedia). Has a right-center editorial bias.

thesmokinggun.com.name: The Smoking Gun
thesmokinggun.com.notes: The Smoking Gun is a website that posts legal documents, arrest records, and police mugshots on a daily basis.  They use sensational headlines to grab attention, but always link to evidence.  Although the information they cover varies there is a slight right bias in word choices.  Otherwise this is a trustworthy site for sensationalized legal and arrest stories.

spectator.co.uk.name: The Spectator (UK)
spectator.co.uk.notes: The Spectator is a weekly British conservative magazine. It was first published on 6 July 1828, making it the oldest continuously published magazine in the English language. It is currently owned by David and Frederick Barclay who also own The Daily Telegraph newspaper, via Press Holdings. Its principal subject areas are politics and culture. Its editorial outlook is generally supportive of the Conservative Party (Wikipedia).

tennessean.com.name: The Tennessean
tennessean.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Tennessee that is usually factual with a right-center editorial bias.

thetimes.co.uk.name: The Times of London
thetimes.co.uk.notes: The Times is a British daily (Monday to Saturday) national newspaper based in London, England. It began in 1785 under the title The Daily Universal Register, adopting its current name on 1 January 1788. The Times and its sister paper The Sunday Times (founded in 1821) are published by Times Newspapers, since 1981 a subsidiary of News UK, itself wholly owned by News Corp (Wikipedia). Has a right-center editorial bias, but is generally factual in reporting.

wsj.com.name: Wall Street Journal
wsj.com.notes: The Wall Street Journal is a high circulation daily financial newspaper from New York City.  The WSJ is Right-Center for a very specific reason.  Their news reporting is excellent and usually very centrist with little bias, however their editorial page is moderately to significantly right.  Therefore, we say Right-Center overall.

washingtonexaminer.com.name: Washington Examiner
washingtonexaminer.com.notes: The Washington Examiner is an American political journalism website and weekly magazine based in Washington, D.C. that covers politics and policy in the United States and internationally.  The publication is influential with conservative circles in politics and government-related fields.

washingtontimes.com.name: Washington Times
washingtontimes.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Washington DC that was one of the first broadsheets in the United States to adopt color photography. The political leanings of The Washington Times are often described as conservative. (Wikipedia) They do usually source well and can be reasonably trusted for their reporting.

watchdog.org.name: Watchdog.org
watchdog.org.notes: Watchdog.org is a network of American news websites that features reporting on state and local government from a conservative perspective. It is a project of the Franklin Center for Government and Public Integrity, an online news organization. Watchdog posts stories on Watchdog websites and syndicates them (Wikipedia). Usually well sourced with minimal loaded words. This source is funded by the fossil fuel industry and promotes anti-science stories regarding climate change.

rep-am.com.name: Waterbury Republican-American
rep-am.com.notes: The Republican-American, is a family-owned newspaper based in Waterbury, Connecticut. Has a right-center editorial bias.

wikileaks.org.name: WikiLeaks
wikileaks.org.notes: WikiLeaks is an international non-profit organization that publishes secret information, news leaks, and classified media from anonymous sources.  Julian Assange, an Australian Internet activist, is generally described as its founder, editor-in-chief, and director. Although it is believed that WikiLeaks publishing of classified/secret material is authentic they have been accused of promoting conspiracy theories against Hillary Clinton and the Democratic Party of the United States (See Wikipedia).  So while the material dumps are not biased they have demonstrated a political agenda.  Therefore, rather than a Least Biased rating we are moving them to Right-Center until more information comes in.

journalnow.com.name: Winston-Salem Journal
journalnow.com.notes: The Winston-Salem Journal is an American daily newspaper primarily serving the city of Winston-Salem, North Carolina, and its county, Forsyth County, North Carolina.  The paper typically endorses Republican candidates.

100percentfedup.com.name: 100 Percent Fed Up
100percentfedup.com.notes: A news website and blog that has extreme right wing bias in reporting and does not source facts well.  Promotes conspiracies.

aim.org.name: Accuracy in Media (AIM)
aim.org.notes: Accuracy In Media (AIM) is an American non-profit news media watchdog founded in 1969 by economist Reed Irvine. AIM describes itself as “a non-profit, grassroots citizens watchdog of the news media that critiques botched and bungled news stories and sets the record straight on important issues that have received slanted coverage.” It has been described as having a politically conservative stance (Wikipedia). This description via Wikipedia misses the mark.  This is an extreme right wing source that often resorts to conspiracy and bigotry. They also promote pseudoscience such as intelligent design and anti-science positions on climate change.

allenbwest.com.name: Allen B. West
allenbwest.com.notes: Col. Allen West is a retired Lieutenant Colonel and the former Republican Representative from Florida’s 22nd district.  His website is a news and information site that has a far right bias and occasionally publishes right wing conspiracy theories.

aei.org.name: American Enterprise Institute
aei.org.notes: American Enterprise Institute, or AEI, is a conservative think tank based in Washington, D.C. Its research is dedicated to issues of government, politics, economics and social welfare. Corporately funded.  Has a poor track record with scientific consensus and occasionally publishes conspiracy theories.

americansforprosperity.org.name: Americans for Prosperity
americansforprosperity.org.notes: Americans for Prosperity (AFP), founded in 2004, is a conservative political advocacy group in the United States. Receiving funding from the businessmen and philanthropist brothers David H. Koch and Charles Koch, it is one of the most influential American conservative organizations.  (Wikipedia)

spectator.org.name: American Spectator
spectator.org.notes: The American Spectator, is a conservative U.S. monthly magazine covering news and politics, edited by R. Emmett Tyrrell, Jr. and published by the non-profit American Spectator Foundation.  Primarily focuses on economics with a right wing bias.

americanthinker.com.name: American Thinker
americanthinker.com.notes: American Thinker is a conservative daily online magazine dealing with American politics, foreign policy, national security, Israel, economics, diplomacy, culture and military strategy. (Wikipedia) Has an obvious right wing bias, but for the most part is mostly factual in reporting.

awm.com.name: American Web Media (AWM)
awm.com.notes: American Web Media is a news and opinion website that covers a variety of topics, including politics. AWM reports with a right wing bias in story selection, but uses minimal loaded words. They don’t always source in their articles which makes it difficult to fact check their information.

ammoland.com.name: Ammoland
ammoland.com.notes: Ammoland is a pro-gun/2nd amendment website that claims to be “the web’s leading Shooting Sports News Service  for the Ammunition, Firearms, Shooting, Hunting and Conservation communities. Ammoland reports on political issues with a strong right wing political affiliation, but uses minimal loaded words and typically sources to credible information.

beinglibertarian.com.name: Being Libertarian
beinglibertarian.com.notes: Being Libertarian is a news, opinion and information website with a libertarian bias.  Being Libertarian does not use strong loaded words and does source to mostly appropriate sources, but almost all content is right leaning. They also reject the consensus of science on anthropogenic climate change.

biggovernment.news.name: Big Government News
biggovernment.news.notes: Big Government News is a website that is geared toward limited government and regulations.  Does not have an About Page to describe who and what they are.  Presents information with a right wing bias in reporting and sometimes sources to poor sources.

bizpacreview.com.name: Bizpac Review
bizpacreview.com.notes: BIZPAC Review, Inc. operates a news and opinion Website that covers conservative news.  Has a strong right-wing bias in reporting choices and does not always source well.

bluelivesmatter.blue.name: Blue Lives Matter
bluelivesmatter.blue.notes: Blue Lives Matter is a pro-police movement in the United States. It was started after the killings of NYPD officers Rafael Ramos and Wenjian Liu in Brooklyn, New York, on December 20, 2014, after they were ambushed in their patrol car. Blue Lives Matter was formed in reaction to the Black Lives Matter movement, which seeks to end police brutality against the African American community. (Wikipedia) Blue Lives Matter presents news with a pro-Donald Trump/Republican bias. They typically source to real news stories.

breitbart.com.name: Breitbart
breitbart.com.notes: Breitbart News Network is a politically conservative American news and opinion website founded in 2007 by conservative commentator and entrepreneur Andrew Breitbart (1969–2012). It also has a daily radio program, Breitbart News Daily.  The content ranges from extreme right wing bias to conspiracy to racism (“Then you see President Barack Hussein Obama waving the line-cutters forward. He’s on their side.  In fact, isn’t he a line-cutter too?  How did this fatherless black guy pay for Harvard?”).  Breitbart has been accused of publishing fake news for the purpose of a political agenda.

campaignlifecoalition.com.name: Campaign Life Coalition
campaignlifecoalition.com.notes: The Campaign Life Coalition is a Canadian non-partisan political lobbyist organization founded in 1978. Based in Toronto, the organization advocates for socially conservative values. In addition to its initial goals of opposing abortion and euthanasia, Campaign Life Coalition advocates for what is considers traditional family values including opposition to same-sex marriage (Wikipedia).

canadafreepress.com.name: Canada Free Press
canadafreepress.com.notes: Judi Ann T. McLeod (born 1944) is a Canadian journalist who operates the conservative Canadian website, Canada Free Press (CFP), which publishes news stories, features, and editorials. The main page of the website uses the title “Canada Free Press …Because without America there is no Free World” and features a “Countdown until Obama leaves Office (Wikipedia).” Has a strong Christian Right bias.

chicksontheright.com.name: Chicks on the Right
chicksontheright.com.notes: Chicks on the Right started as blog/website and has now also become a right wing radio program.  Has right wing bias in reporting and wording.  Some times promotes false information.

christianpost.com.name: Christian Post
christianpost.com.notes: The Christian Post is a news and opinion website that has a Christian right bias in reporting.  They are generally factual in reporting, but not always when reporting science.

chroniclesmagazine.org.name: Chronicles Magazine (Rockford)
chroniclesmagazine.org.notes: Chronicles is a U.S. monthly magazine published by the Rockford Institute. Its full current name is Chronicles: A Magazine of American Culture. The magazine is known for promoting anti-globalism, anti-intervention and anti-immigration stances within conservative politics, and is considered one of the leading paleoconservative publications (Wikipedia).

citizensunited.org.name: Citizens United
citizensunited.org.notes: Citizens United’s goal is to restore the founding fathers’ vision of a free nation, guided by the honesty, common sense, and good will of its citizens.  Works as a right wing lobby group. Has a right wing bias in reporting and is not always evidence based.

city-journal.org.name: City Journal
city-journal.org.notes: City Journal is a quarterly magazine published by the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, a conservative think tank based in New York City. Has a conservative bias in reporting.  Usually sources information.

cnsnews.com.name: CNS News
cnsnews.com.notes: CNSNews.com (formerly known as Cybercast News Service) is a politically conservative American news and commentary website founded by L. Brent Bozell III and owned by Media Research Center, Bozell’s Reston, Virginia-based organization (Wikipedia). Has strong conservative bias with wording and story choices.  Some articles use racist language such as referring to Blacks as Thugs.

colddeadhands.us.name: Cold Dead Hands
