colddeadhands.us.notes: Cold Dead Hands (CDH, Inc.) states that they are an “unapologetic for-profit corporation AND an American grassroots movement with politically incorrect, yet sound Founding Father doctrine and principles, created as a new breed of advocacy that fully embraces all that is American.” Translation: they are a right wing biased 2nd amendment advocacy group.

commentarymagazine.com.name: Commentary Magazine
commentarymagazine.com.notes: Commentary is a monthly American magazine on religion, Judaism, and politics, as well as social and cultural issues. Besides its strong coverage of cultural issues, Commentary provided a strong voice for the anti-Stalinist left.  Norman Podhoretz the founder, originally a liberal Democrat turned neoconservative, moved the magazine to the right and toward the Republican Party in the 1970s and 1980s (Wikipedia). Well sourced information with a right wing bias in wording and story selection.

conservativehq.com.name: Conservative HQ
conservativehq.com.notes: Conservative HQ is a news and opinion website with a right wing bias in reporting and wording.  Does not always source information to credible sources.

conservativeoutfitters.com.name: Conservative Outfitters
conservativeoutfitters.com.notes: Conservative Outfitters seems like a legitimate website but in fact they are stealing others contents to generate clicks.  The content they are stealing is highly biased right wing stories.

conservativepost.com.name: Conservative Post
conservativepost.com.notes: The Conservative Post is a news and opinion website with Extreme right wing/conservative bias in content and wording.  Content is sometimes so over the top it is difficult to tell if it is serious or satire.  Articles contain racist content and most are not factual.

conservativereview.com.name: Conservative Review
conservativereview.com.notes: According to the website the “mission of Conservative Review is to provide best-in-class analysis and commentary on conservative political speech, votes, positions, and elections.” Conservative Review also has website that is dedicated to streaming conservative shows such as Mark Levin and Michelle Malkin.  This source has a right-wing bias in reporting and sometimes sources to other biased media outlets..

rickwells.us.name: Constitution Rising
rickwells.us.notes: This is essentially a right wing blog with  very strong conservative bias in reporting.  Not always factual or sourced.

controversialtimes.com.name: Controversial Times
controversialtimes.com.notes: The Controversial Times is a right wing news and opinion source that has very strong bias and sometimes does not source to proper credible information.

crimeresearch.org.name: Crime Prevention Research Center
crimeresearch.org.notes: The Crime Prevention Research Center is a nonprofit founded in 2013 by John Lott, author of the book “More Gun, Less Crime.”  He is best known as an advocate in the gun rights debate, particularly his arguments against restrictions on owning and carrying guns.  Lott’s work has been called “junk science” as he has been accused of accepting funding the National Rifle Association. Lott denies this claim (Wikipedia).  Any claims made on this website need to be fact checked with credible sources.

dailycaller.com.name: Daily Caller
dailycaller.com.notes: The Daily Caller is an American news and opinion website based in Washington, D.C.. It was founded by Tucker Carlson, a libertarian conservative political pundit, and Neil Patel, former adviser to former Vice President Dick Cheney (Wikipedia).  The Daily Caller produces sensational headlines and has a right wing bias in reporting and has made false claims according to Snopes and Politifact.

express.co.uk.name: Daily Express
express.co.uk.notes: The Daily Express is a daily national tabloid newspaper in the United Kingdom. Has right wing populism views in reporting.

thedailyliberator.com.name: The Daily Liberator
thedailyliberator.com.notes: The Daily Liberator is a Libertarian news and opinion website.  It claims to be your source for Liberty related news.  Has questionable views on science and has a strong anti-liberal bias.

dailymail.co.uk.name: Daily Mail
dailymail.co.uk.notes: The Daily Mail is a British daily middle-market tabloid newspaper owned by the Daily Mail and General Trust and published in London (Wikipedia). Has a strong conservative bias and has a poor track record with fact checkers.

dailysabah.com.name: Daily Sabah
dailysabah.com.notes: Daily Sabah is an English, German and Arabic-language daily newspaper published in Turkey and owned by Turkuvaz Media Group. Foreign Policy has labeled the Daily Sabah as a mouthpiece of the AKP and especially Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, the current president of Turkey. (Wikipedia)  Reports USA news with a right of center bias.

dailysignal.com.name: Daily Signal
dailysignal.com.notes: The Daily Signal is a conservative American news website founded in June 2014. The publication focuses on politics, culture, and other stories. It is published by The Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank. Very strong right bias in reporting and wording.  Does not always source to credible information.

horowitzfreedomcenter.org.name: David Horowitz Freedom Center
horowitzfreedomcenter.org.notes: The David Horowitz Freedom Center, formerly the Center for the Study of Popular Culture (CSPC), is a conservative foundation founded in 1988 by political activist David Horowitz (Wikipedia).  Has a very strong conservative and anti-Islam bias.

dcstatesman.com.name: DC Statesman
dcstatesman.com.notes: The DC Statesman is a news and opinion website with a very strong right wing bias.  They utilize loaded headlines and do not always source their information to other credible sources.

debatepost.com.name: Debate Post
debatepost.com.notes: The Debate Post is a Canadian news and opinion website. The Debate posts has moderate right wing bias in story selection, but uses minimal loaded words and tends to source to mostly credible sources, however there are a few articles that source to far right sources such as Breitbart.

discoverthenetworks.org.name: Discover the Networks
discoverthenetworks.org.notes: Discover the Networks (originally Discover the Network) is a website run by the David Horowitz Freedom Center that focuses on the individuals, groups, and history of groups alleged to be political left wing.  The website has been criticized for including leftists on the same list as Islamists. (Wikipedia)

disobedientmedia.com.name: Disobedient Media
disobedientmedia.com.notes: Disobedient Media is a news and opinion website with a right wing bias in story selection and reporting. Disobedient Media uses moderate loaded words and tends to source well to credible information. Occasionally they will source to some pretty far right sources.

drudgereport.com.name: Drudge Report
drudgereport.com.notes: The Drudge Report is a politically conservative American news aggregation website run by Matt Drudge. The site consists mainly of links to stories from the United States and international mainstream media about politics, entertainment, and current events; it also has links to many columnists. Occasionally, Drudge authors new stories himself, based on tips. (Wikipedia) The Drudge Report focuses on sensationalized stories with a right wing bias.

factsandlogic.org.name: Facts and Logic About the Middle East (FLAME)
factsandlogic.org.notes: Facts and Logic About the Middle East (FLAME) is a non-profit pro-Israel organization based in San Francisco, California. Its stated purpose is “the research and publication of the facts regarding developments in the Middle East and exposing false propaganda that might harm the interests of the United States and its allies in that area of the world (Wikipedia).” The source has an extreme bias for Israel and against Muslims. According to the The Village Voice, when a reporter “pointed out the overt bigotry” in a FLAME ad in 1998 that described Islam as “virulent” and blamed it for promoting violence against the U.S. and Israel, FLAME’s Gerardo Joffe said “All Arab Muslims may not be a bunch of fanatics, but I’ve never met one who isn’t.”

familysecuritymatters.org.name: Family Security Matters
familysecuritymatters.org.notes: Family Security Matters is a conservative website affiliated with Frank Gaffney’s conspiracy think tank the Center for Security Policy. Although this source does embrace conspiracies involving Islam, it is more of  an extreme right wing news source.

federalistpress.com.name: Federalist Press
federalistpress.com.notes: The Federalist Press is a news and opinion website with strong right bias in reporting and wording.  Not always sourced well, but does report factual news more often than not with a variety of loaded words.

foxnews.com.name: Fox News
foxnews.com.notes: Fox News Channel, also known as Fox News, is an American basic cable and satellite news television channel that is owned by the Fox Entertainment Group subsidiary of 21st Century Fox (Wikipedia). Fox News Channel has been accused of biased reporting and promoting the Republican Party and has been deemed the least accurate cable news source according to Politifact.

freedomworks.org.name: Freedom Works
freedomworks.org.notes: FreedomWorks is a conservative and libertarian advocacy group based in Washington D.C., United States. FreedomWorks trains volunteers, assists in campaigns, and encourages them to mobilize, interacting with both fellow citizens and their political representatives. It is widely associated with the Tea Party movement.  Right wing bias in reporting and some campaign ads have not been factual.

frontpagemag.com.name: Frontpage Magazine
frontpagemag.com.notes: FrontPage Magazine is an online conservative political website, edited by David Horowitz and published by the David Horowitz Freedom Center, a non-profit organization in Los Angeles, California (Wikipedia).  This source has a pretty strong right wing bias in reporting that often is negative toward minorities and Islam.

futureinamerica.com.name: Future in America
futureinamerica.com.notes: Future in America is a conservative Super PAC that also publishes highly biased right wing news that is not always 100% factual.

gatestoneinstitute.org.name: Gatestone Institute
gatestoneinstitute.org.notes: The Gatestone Institute, formerly Stonegate Institute, is a “not-for-profit international policy council and think tank based in New York City” with a specialization in strategy and defense issues (Wikipedia). Gatestone Institute is  anti-Islamic, pro-Christian and Jewish/Israel. Many of the articles will link back to sites that don’t say what they claim or make the same rash judgments, without proof. Example: Obama tells Christians to not protest in Egypt then has no quotes or sources saying he said that (M. Allen).

g-a-i.org.name: Government Accountability Institute
g-a-i.org.notes: The Government Accountability Institute (GAI) is a conservative nonprofit investigative research organization located in Tallahassee, Florida. GAI was founded in 2012. Has a right wing bias in reporting and generally sources to legit info, but will cherry pick.

heartland.org.name: Heartland Institute
heartland.org.notes: The Heartland Institute is an American conservative and libertarian public policy think tank founded in 1984.  The Institute conducts work on issues including education reform, government spending, taxation, healthcare, education, tobacco policy, global warming, hydraulic fracturing, information technology, and free-market environmentalism.  The Heartland Institute became a leading supporter of climate change denial. It rejects the scientific consensus on global warming, and says that policies to fight it would be damaging to the economy.  They are heavily funded by corporations involved in the fossil fuel industry (Wikipedia).

heritage.org.name: Heritage Foundation
heritage.org.notes: The Heritage Foundation is an American conservative think tank based in Washington, D.C. The foundation took a leading role in the conservative movement during the presidency of Ronald Reagan, whose policies were taken from Heritage’s policy study Mandate for Leadership.  Heritage has since continued to have a significant influence in U.S. public policy making, and is considered to be one of the most influential conservative research organizations in the United States (Wikipedia). Occasionally, uses loaded words and does not always source to credible information. Has been put on a list by the Union of Concerned Scientists for publishing misleading information regarding climate change.

heatst.com.name: Heat Street
heatst.com.notes: Heat Street is a conservative opinion and commentary website. Launched in February 2016, the website is headed by British writer and former politician Louise Mensch. It is owned by News Corp under Dow Jones & Company. (Wikipedia) This source has a right wing bias through wording and story selection.

hotair.com.name: Hot Air
hotair.com.notes: Hot Air is a conservative American political blog. It is written by the pseudonymous Allahpundit, Ed Morrissey, John Sexton, and Jazz Shaw. Hot Air was founded by Michelle Malkin, a conservative author and blogger, in 2006 (Wikipedia). The writers vary in biases, but all are to the right.

hudson.org.name: Hudson Institute
hudson.org.notes: The Hudson Institute is an American conservative non-profit think tank based in Washington, D.C.. It was founded in 1961 in Croton-on-Hudson, New York, by futurist, military strategist, and systems theorist Herman Kahn and his colleagues at the RAND Corporation (Wikipedia). Has right wing bias in reporting and story choices.  Well sourced.

humanevents.com.name: Human Events
humanevents.com.notes: An online conservative magazine.  Regular writers have included Robert Novak, Ann Coulter, Terence P. Jeffrey, Pat Buchanan, and John Gizzi, its chief political editor. Occasional contributors have included Sean Hannity, Newt Gingrich, and Paul Craig Roberts, and Cliff Kincaid.

ijr.com.name: Independent Journal Review
ijr.com.notes: The Independent Journal Review is an American news website founded in 2012. It has over 35 million visitors a month, making it one of the top fifty websites in the United States (Wikipedia).  Has significant right wing bias through story selection that favors conservatives and is against liberals. Occasionally uses loaded words in headlines and articles, but tends to source to mostly credible information. Has not been reviewed for any false claims through the major fact checkers.

judicialnetwork.com.name: Judicial Crisis Network
judicialnetwork.com.notes: The Judicial Crisis Network (JCN) (originally founded as the Judicial Confirmation Network) is an American conservative political campaign organization based in the United States. As of 2014 it was run by Carrie Severino, a former law clerk for Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas (Wikipedia). In January, JCN launched a 10 million dollar campaign to support Donald Trump’s supreme court nominee. On the website they report news about the judicial system with a strong right wing bias through the use of loaded words and linking to other right biased sources.

judicialwatch.org.name: Judicial Watch
judicialwatch.org.notes: Judicial Watch is a conservative educational foundation that promotes transparency, accountability and integrity in government, politics and the law. Unfortunately, Judicial Watch is not always accountable and publishes false information according to Politifact and Snopes.

knoxreport.com.name: Knox Report
knoxreport.com.notes: The Knox Report is a highly biased conservative source that used loaded words and sometimes does not source to credible information.

legalinsurrection.com.name: Legal Insurrection
legalinsurrection.com.notes: Legal Insurrection is a conservative blog created by William A. Jacobson who is an American lawyer and professor. Legal Insurretion uses a good deal of loaded language in its headlines and within its articles. Their articles/commentaries are mainly from right wing sources and bloggers giving opinions on current news. (F. Locke Siewert)

lewrockwell.com.name: Lew Rockwell
lewrockwell.com.notes: Lew Rockwell is libertarian news and opinion source that promotes many conspiracies and some pseudoscience.

libertyalliance.com.name: Liberty Alliance
libertyalliance.com.notes: Liberty Alliance, LLC is a private United States company with its headquarters in Atlanta, Georgia which operates a collection of conservative and Christian websites.  Outside of hosting overtly right wing websites they also host a fair share of conspiracy sites.

libertyhangout.org.name: Liberty Hangout
libertyhangout.org.notes: Liberty Hangout is a libertarian news and opinion website.  Has a typical economic right wing bias and moderate left social bias.  It uses loaded words, but not overtly.  It typically sources information, but sometimes to far right or non-credible sources.

libertynews.com.name: Liberty News
libertynews.com.notes: A news and opinion website that has extreme right wing bias in reporting and does not always source facts well.  Takes conservative positions such as being opposed to a minimum wage and against equal rights for LGBT. Sometimes promotes conspiracies.

libertytalk.fm.name: LibertyTalk.FM
libertytalk.fm.notes: LibertyTalk.FM is a website that connects people to live streams of right wing talk shows.  All shows have a strong right wing bias and some are conspiracy shows such as the Alex Jones Show.

libertyunyielding.com.name: Liberty Unyielding
libertyunyielding.com.notes: Liberty Unyielding is a website that publishes original content as well as aggregated news from other sources.  All original content has a strong right wing bias.  Aggregated content is dependent on the source.

lifenews.com.name: Life News
lifenews.com.notes: Life News is a news and opinion website that is focused on Pro-Life issues. They have a far right political bias and occasionally uses loaded words. They also source to other right wing biased or pseudoscience sources.

lifesitenews.com.name: Life Site News
lifesitenews.com.notes: LifeSiteNews “is a non-profit Internet service dedicated to issues of culture, life, and family.”  The website was founded by the Campaign Life Coalition which has a far right bias. Both sources are anti-abortion and opposed to gay marriage.

lifezette.com.name: LifeZette
lifezette.com.notes: LifeZette is an American news, opinion, and commentary website based in Washington, D.C.. It was founded in 2015 by conservative pundit and radio host Laura Ingraham.  Typical right wing bias in reporting and wording.

unionleader.com.name: Manchester Union Leader
unionleader.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Manchester, New Hampshire with a right wing bias in reporting.

mrc.org.name: Media Research Center (MRC)
mrc.org.notes: The Media Research Center (MRC) is a politically conservative content analysis organization based in Reston, Virginia, founded in 1987 by activist L. Brent Bozell III. Its stated mission is to “prove—through sound scientific research—that liberal bias in the media does exist and undermines traditional American values.” (Wikipedia) Unfortunately, this source needs its content analyzed as it is very biased toward the right.

nationalreview.com.name: National Review
nationalreview.com.notes: National Review (NR) is a semi-monthly magazine founded by author William F. Buckley, Jr. in 1955. Although the print version of the magazine is available online to subscribers, the free content on the website is essentially a separate publication under different editorial direction. The online version, National Review Online, describes itself as “America’s most widely read and influential magazine and web site for conservative news, commentary, and opinion (Wikipedia).”  Has a right wing bias in reporting, but is well sourced and mostly factual with news.

home.nra.org.name: National Rifle Association (NRA)
home.nra.org.notes: The National Rifle Association of America (NRA) is an American nonprofit organization which advocates for gun rights.  Observers and lawmakers see the NRA as one of the top three most influential lobbying groups in Washington (Wikipedia). The NRA has a right wing bias as it supports Republican candidates and alleges that Democrats are attempting to restrict gun rights. The NRA has mixed track record with Politifact.

newsbusters.org.name: Newsbusters
newsbusters.org.notes: Newbusters claims to expose liberal bias, however this site is one of the most extreme right wing biased sites out there.  Could also fall into the conspiracy category, but it does publish real news also.

newsmax.com.name: Newsmax
newsmax.com.notes: Newsmax Media, commonly called Newsmax, is an American news media organization founded by Christopher Ruddy and based in West Palm Beach, Florida. It operates a multiplatform network focused on conservative-leaning media, including the news website Newsmax.com, publishes the Franklin Prosperity Report and Newsmax magazine, and the cable news channel Newsmax TV (Wikipedia).  This source has a right wing bias in reporting and wording.  Mostly factual and sourced news, but sometimes takes news out of context.

newrevolutionnow.org.name: New Revolution Now
newrevolutionnow.org.notes: According the About page New Revolution Now is a non-profit, party-neutral organization created to support and advocate for core foundational American principles. Our Institute performs educational activities, outreach and organizing, legislative activism and endorsement.  Their goals as stated on the website is to harness  the core conservative values of mainstream  Americans to elect the state and US  congressional representatives who will return  the country to its founding values of  limited government, low taxation, states rights,  and constitutional constructionism. This source really doesn’t publish news, but it has a strong right wing political bias through its endorsement of conservative candidates.

observer.com.name: New York Observer
observer.com.notes: The New York Observer is owned by Jared Kushner who is the husband of Ivanka Trump and son-in-law to Donald Trump.  This source has a strong right wing political bias. Has published some unproven stories according to Snopes.

nextnewsnetwork.com.name: Next News Network
nextnewsnetwork.com.notes: Next News Network was founded by radical Zionist Gary Franchi as an alternative news source.  This source has strong pro-Israel bias and right wing bias with American politics.

numbersusa.com.name: Numbers USA
numbersusa.com.notes: NumbersUSA is an immigration reduction organization that seeks to reduce US immigration levels to pre-1965 levels without country of origin quotas as established in the Immigration Act of 1924 (Wikipedia).  NumbersUSA was founded by Roy Beck while he worked for anti-immigration activist John Tanton, who has been described as a racist. NumbersUSA is also connected to the Federation for American Immigration Reform and the Center for Immigration studies, via John Tanton. Both of these groups are considered to be racist organizations, however, NumbersUSA does not promote against immigration from Non-Eurocentric countries. We therefore rate them Right Biased based on their political affiliation, rather than Questionable.

oann.com.name: One America News Network
oann.com.notes: Originally envisioned as a conservative-oriented news network, OAN’s stated focus is delivering a credible source of national and international news 24/7. OAN features news programming and political talk shows, along with network special documentary-style reports. Its news coverage attempts to maintain objectivity while its political talk shows illustrate a strong conservative view (Wikipedia).

onenewsnow.com.name: OneNewsNow
onenewsnow.com.notes: OneNewsNow is a news and opinion website with a very strong Christian Right bias.  OneNewsNow publishes unscientific news stories and does not source to legitimate sources.  They do post some serious news that is not related to politics, that is fairly balanced.

pjmedia.com.name: PJ Media
pjmedia.com.notes: PJ Media (originally known as Pajamas Media) is an American online media company and operator of an eponymous conservative news, opinion and commentary collaborative blog that was founded in 2004 (Wikipedia). Has a right wing bias in reporting and content.

politicalears.com.name: Political Ears
politicalears.com.notes: Political ears is an extreme right wing site that is either deliberate satire or just plain conspiracies.  Either way the content is far right.

thepoliticalinsider.com.name: Political Insider
thepoliticalinsider.com.notes: A political news and opinion website with a strong conservative bias.  Can be unreliable for facts and sometimes publishes right wing conspiracy theories.

politichicks.com.name: Politichicks
politichicks.com.notes: Politichicks is a very conservative right wing web tv show.  Does not shy from right wing conspiracies and may require fact checking from credible sources on certain stories.

powerlineblog.com.name: Power Line
powerlineblog.com.notes: Power Line is an American conservative political blog, founded in May 2002.  Power Line often vigorously criticizes Democrats and liberals for dishonesty, lack of morals, bad judgment and disloyalty to the United States (Wikipedia). While this source has a very strong opinion bias they do report news with proper sources.

projectveritas.com.name: Project Veritas
projectveritas.com.notes: Project Veritas was created by James Edward O’Keefe III who is an American conservative political activist. He produces secretly recorded undercover audio and video encounters, some selectively edited to imply its subjects said things they did not, with figures and workers in academic, governmental and social service organizations, purporting to show abusive or allegedly illegal behavior by employees and/or representatives of those organizations. (Wikipedia)  Project Veritas primarily targets liberals and liberal organizations.  O’Keefe’s videos are edited in a way that makes them difficult to fact check.  Often his information is debunked, but it is too late as the information has already been watched by thousands or more.

redalertpolitics.com.name: Red Alert Politics
redalertpolitics.com.notes: Red Alert Politics states that it is an online publication written by young conservatives for young conservatives. It is published by MediaDC, which also publishes The Weekly Standard and The Washington Examiner.  This source has a right wing bias in reporting and wording.  It is average for sourcing and is moderately trustworthy for accuracy of information.

redflagnews.com.name: Red Flag News
redflagnews.com.notes: Red Flag News is a news and opinion website that reports with extreme right wing bias. Although they do publish real news, many stories are not properly sourced or are simply conspiracy theories. Has a dismal fact checking record.

redstate.com.name: Red State
redstate.com.notes: Red State is a highly biased American conservative political blog. Not all writers publish factual/sourced information.

redstatewatcher.com.name: Red State Watcher
redstatewatcher.com.notes: Red State Watcher is a conservative news website that has strong right wing bias in reporting.  Does not always source to credible sources.

regated.com.name: Regated News
regated.com.notes: Regated news is a news and opinion website with a right wing bias in reporting.  Sometimes publishes poorly sourced news.

resistancemedia.org.name: Resistance Media
resistancemedia.org.notes: Resistance Media is a news and opinion website that focuses on public school reform, government transparency and family rights. This source does not provide an “about” or “contact” page so they are automatically discredited as a source. Resistance Media is a far right biased news source that advocates for right wing political objectives. Some information is sourced well and we give them a mixed rating for factual reporting.

secureamericanow.org.name: Secure America Now
secureamericanow.org.notes: Secure America Now (SAN) is a politically conservative nonprofit group that focuses on United States foreign policy issues. It says its mission is to raise security issues “to the forefront of the American debate (Wikpedia).” Has a blog section that presents news with a right wing political bias and has a mostly false rating according to Politifact.

silenceisconsent.net.name: Silence is Consent
silenceisconsent.net.notes: Silence is Consent is a right wing news and opinion website. This source sometimes does not source to credible information.

spiked-online.com.name: Spiked Magazine
spiked-online.com.notes: Spiked is a British Internet magazine focusing on politics, culture and society from a libertarian viewpoint. Spiked focuses on issues of freedom and state control, science and technology, culture, education and literature (Wikipedia). Has a moderate right wing bias in reporting and does not support the consensus of science on environmental issues.

westernjournalism.com/thepoint.name: Tea Party News (The Point)
westernjournalism.com/thepoint.notes: Tea Party News is now called “The Point” and is hosted by Western Journalism. The website still has extreme right wing biased content that is not always factual.

teapartytribune.com.name: Tea Party Tribune
teapartytribune.com.notes: Tea party news source.  Has an extreme right wing bias and occasionally promotes propaganda.

theamericancause.org.name: The American Cause
theamericancause.org.notes: The American Cause is an educational organization whose mission is to advance and promote traditional American values that are rooted in the conservative principles of national sovereignty, economic patriotism, limited government, and individual freedom.

theblacksphere.net.name: The Blacksphere (Kevin Jackson)
theblacksphere.net.notes: According the About Page in this website The Black Sphere team wants to End Identity Politics, educating with satire and humor.  The site content consists of a far right wing bias and does focus heavily on racism.  Keep in mind this is the right wing take on racism.

theblaze.com.name: The Blaze
theblaze.com.notes: TheBlaze is a multiplatform news and entertainment network available on television, radio and the Internet founded by conservative talk radio personality and entrepreneur Glenn Beck (Wikipedia). TheBlaze has a conservative bias in reporting.  Some news stories and television personalities are not always factually accurate.

dailytelegraph.com.au.name: The Daily Telegraph (Australia)
dailytelegraph.com.au.notes: The Daily Telegraph is a conservative, Australian tabloid newspaper published in Sydney, New South Wales, by Nationwide News, part of News Corp.  Known as Australia’s least trusted newspaper (Wikipedia).

dailywire.com.name: The Daily Wire
dailywire.com.notes: The Daily Wire is a politically conservative American news and opinion website founded in 2015 by conservative political commentator Ben Shapiro, who currently serves as Editor-in-chief. Presents news with a right wing bias in reporting and wording.

thefederalist.com.name: The Federalist
thefederalist.com.notes: The Federalist is an English-language online magazine that covers politics, policy, culture, and religion. The Federalist has been described as influential in conservative and libertarian circles (Wikipedia). Has a right wing bias in reporting, but is usually well sourced.

thenewamerican.com.name: The New American
thenewamerican.com.notes: The New American (TNA) is a print magazine published twice a month by American Opinion Publishing Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the John Birch Society.  Displays right wing bias in reporting and does not always follow the consensus of science.

patriotpost.us.name: The Patriot Post
patriotpost.us.notes: The Patriot Post is a Conservative media source promoting individual liberty.  It has a right wing bias in reporting and sometimes does not source to credible information.

thepostemail.com.name: The Post and Email
thepostemail.com.notes: The Post and Email is an online newspaper that is overtly Christian and conservative in bias.

therealstrategy.com.name: The Real Strategy
therealstrategy.com.notes: The Real Strategy is an online news source with a moderate to strong right wing bias.  The source uses sensational headlines to attract readers and some stories have been factually incorrect.

therebel.media.name: The Rebel
therebel.media.notes: The Rebel Media (or The Rebel) is a conservative Canadian online political and social commentary media platform founded in February 2015 by former Sun News Network host Ezra Levant.  Overt right wing bias. Tends to source to other articles on The Rebel website rather than outside sources.

therightscoop.com.name: The Right Scoop
therightscoop.com.notes: The Right Scoop demonstrates fairly typical right wing bias in reporting.  Very similar to Fox News in their bias and approach.

thesun.co.uk.name: The Sun
thesun.co.uk.notes: The Sun is a daily tabloid newspaper published in the United Kingdom and Ireland. As a broadsheet, it was founded in 1964 as a successor to the Daily Herald; it became a tabloid in 1969 after it was purchased by its current owners. It is published by the News Group Newspapers division of News UK, itself a wholly owned subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp.  Bottom line is this tabloid reports trashy ridiculous stories with a right wing bias.

torontosun.com.name: Toronto Sun
torontosun.com.notes: The Toronto Sun is an English-language daily tabloid newspaper published in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. It is known for its daily Sunshine Girl feature and its populist conservative editorial stance (Wikipedia). Uses sensational headlines, but is usually sourced.

townhall.com.name: Townhall
townhall.com.notes: Townhall is an American politically conservative website and print magazine. Previously published by the Heritage Foundation. The website also publishes news articles from the Associated Press (Wikipedia).

tribunist.com.name: Tribunist
tribunist.com.notes: The Tribunist is a right biased online source that uses loaded words and somewhat misleading headlines.

truthinmedia.com.name: Truth in Media
truthinmedia.com.notes: Truth In Media attempts to fact check controversial topics.  While some of the investigations are legitimate some are not.  This source also supports pseudoscience in some cases.

twitchy.com.name: Twitchy
twitchy.com.notes: Twitchy is an American Twitter curation and news website founded by conservative commentator Michelle Malkin in 2012. Has a right wing bias in reporting choices.

unbiasedamerica.com.name: Unbiased America
unbiasedamerica.com.notes: Unbiased America is a news and opinion blog with a moderate right wing bias. Unbiased America’s writers use moderate loaded words in both headlines and in the body of articles. Their stories also slightly favor conservatives and are against liberals. They do attempt to source to credible information, but at times source to other right wing biased sources.

uspoliticsinfo.com.name: US Politics Info
uspoliticsinfo.com.notes: US Politics Info is a news and opinion website with right wing bias in reporting and story selection. Does not always source to credible information.

usapoliticstoday.com.name: USA Politics Today
usapoliticstoday.com.notes: USA Politics Today is a right wing news and opinion website. This source has strong right wing bias in story selection and uses loaded words in headlines and articles. This source also sometimes sources to other right wing sources and has had a false claim with fact checking.

vesselnews.io.name: Vessel News
vesselnews.io.notes: From the Vessel News “about” page: “Vessel News is a different kind of news destination, redefining the right-wing media narrative by combining America’s most transformative phenomenons–anti-establishment conservative politics and technological innovation. Vessel News is a lighting bolt for exposing the leftist agenda, who seek to steal our freedom of speech, right to bear arms and refuse to call by name the enemies of our way of life–Radical. Islamic. Terrorists.”

freebeacon.com.name: Washington Free Beacon
freebeacon.com.notes: The Washington Free Beacon is an American politically conservative political journalism website that publishes news and opinion commentary.  It has a very strong right wing bias and often publishes misleading headlines that do match the content of stories.

weaselzippers.us.name: Weasel Zippers
weaselzippers.us.notes: Weasel Zippers is your basic right wing news blog.  Has pretty typical bias at the more extreme end of right. Not always well sourced.

weeklystandard.com.name: Weekly Standard
weeklystandard.com.notes: The Weekly Standard is an American neoconservative opinion magazine published 48 times per year. Its founding publisher, News Corporation, debuted the title on September 18, 1995. It has a strong right wing editorial bias, but reports news stories with good sourcing.

westernjournalism.com.name: Western Journalism
westernjournalism.com.notes: The Western Journalism Center was founded in 1991 by Joseph Farah and James H. Smith. Based in Sacramento, California, the center produces a popular conservative newsletter. Western Journalism produced highly right wing biased and sensational content.

wnd.com.name: World Net Daily (WND)
wnd.com.notes: Based on reviews by all of our researchers, WND is an online news source that has a far right bias and dabbles in right wing conspiracies such as President Obama’s birth certificate. They also use misleading clickbait headlines that do not always match the content of the article (See M. Allen’s review below). WND also has a mixed track record with fact checkers: here and here (D. Van Zandt). Below is the detailed reviews of each researcher.

yellowhammernews.com.name: YellowHammer News
yellowhammernews.com.notes: Yellowhammer News is a conservative news site covering politics and culture in the state of Alabama. The site was founded in 2011. The website produces quality journalism with a moderate right wing bias.

youngcons.com.name: Young Conservatives
youngcons.com.notes: Young or old, they publish the same old far right biased stories and conspiracies. Extreme loaded words and poorly sourced information.

airspacemag.com.name: Air & Space Magazine
airspacemag.com.notes: Air & Space/Smithsonian magazine is a bimonthly magazine put out by the National Air and Space Museum.

aaas.org.name: American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS)
aaas.org.notes: The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) is an American international non-profit organization with the stated goals of promoting cooperation among scientists, defending scientific freedom, encouraging scientific responsibility, and supporting scientific education and science outreach for the betterment of all humanity. It is the world’s largest general scientific society, with over 120,000 members, and is the publisher of the well-known scientific journal Science. (Wikipedia)

aip.org.name: The American Institute of Physics
aip.org.notes: The American Institute of Physics (AIP) promotes science, the profession of physics, publishes physics journals, and produces publications for scientific and engineering societies. The AIP is made up of various member societies. Its corporate headquarters are at the American Center for Physics in College Park, Maryland, but the institute also has offices in Melville, New York and Beijing (Wikipedia).

ajaonline.org.name: American Journal of Archaeology
ajaonline.org.notes: The American Journal of Archaeology (AJA), the peer-reviewed journal of the Archaeological Institute of America, has been published since 1897.

archaeology.org.name: Archaeology Magazine
archaeology.org.notes: Archaeology magazine is a bimonthly mainstream publication for the general public, supported by its website archaeology.org.  The magazine is published by the Archaeological Institute of America. The institute also publishes the professional American Journal of Archaeology. (Wikipedia)

arstechnica.com.name: Ars Technica
arstechnica.com.notes: Ars Technica is a technology news and information website. It publishes news, reviews, and guides on issues such as computer hardware and software, science, technology policy, and video games. Many of the site’s writers are postgraduates and some work for research institutions. Articles on the website are written in a less-formal tone than those in traditional journals (Wikipedia).

skeptics.com.au.name: Australian Skeptics Inc.
skeptics.com.au.notes: Australian Skeptics is a loose confederation of groups across Australia that investigate paranormal and pseudo-scientific claims from a responsible scientific viewpoint.

climateactiontracker.org.name: Climate Action Tracker
climateactiontracker.org.notes: Climate Action Tracker is an independent science-based assessment, which tracks the emission commitments and actions of countries. The website provides an up-to-date assessment of individual national pledges to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions. They have a well sourced Methodology.

csicop.org.name: Committee for Skeptical Inquiry
csicop.org.notes: The Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI), is a program within the transnational American non-profit educational organization Center for Inquiry (CFI), which seeks to “promote scientific inquiry, critical investigation, and the use of reason in examining controversial and extraordinary claims.” (Wikipedia)

contrailscience.com.name: Contrail Science
contrailscience.com.notes: Contrail Science is a website that explains contrails and debunks the chemtrail conspiracy/pseudoscience theories through the use of evidence.

discovermagazine.com.name: Discover Magazine
discovermagazine.com.notes: Discover is an American general audience science magazine launched in October 1980 by Time Inc. It has been owned by Kalmbach Publishing since 2010.  (Wikipedia)

doubtfulnews.com.name: Doubtful News
doubtfulnews.com.notes: Doubtful News is a privately-owned, science and evidence based site  by Lithospherica, LLC. They help their audience see beyond the news headlines and fantastic anecdotes. Is well sourced and scientific in approach.

fas.org.name: Federation of American Scientists (FAS)
fas.org.notes: The Federation of American Scientists (FAS) is a 501(c)(3) organization with the stated intent of using science and scientific analysis to attempt to make the world more secure. FAS was founded in 1945 by scientists who worked on the Manhattan Project to develop the first atomic bombs (Wikipedia).

journal.frontiersin.org.name: Frontiers In Psychology
journal.frontiersin.org.notes: Frontiers in Psychology is an open access journal that aims at publishing the best research across the entire field of psychology.

geneticliteracyproject.org.name: Genetic Literacy Project
geneticliteracyproject.org.notes: According to The Genetic Literacy Project (GLP) they “explore the intersection of DNA research and real world applications of genetics with the media and policy worlds in order to disentangle science from ideology.”  The GLP has been accused of accepting funding from corporations that are involved in the agriculture genetics business due to their acceptance of the consensus of science as it relates to GMO’s.  On the GLP website they offer a full disclosure of their funding which indicates they do not receive funding from Pro-GMO companies such as Monsanto.

geologyin.com.name: Geology In
geologyin.com.notes: Geology In publishes news related to geology.  Most articles are aggregated from other reputable science journals and magazines. This source does use some clickbait type headlining and the site has quite a few ads. Otherwise this is a decent science site.

iflscience.com.name: IFL Science
iflscience.com.notes: IFL Science is a website that publishes the lighter side of science.  A word of caution with IFL Science is they do present some stories with a left of center bias.

web.randi.org.name: James Randi Educational Foundation
web.randi.org.notes: The James Randi Educational Foundation (JREF) was started as an American non-profit organization founded in 1996 by magician and skeptic James Randi. The JREF’s mission includes educating the public and the media on the dangers of accepting unproven claims, and to support research into paranormal claims in controlled scientific experimental conditions (Wikipedia).

jstor.org.name: JStor
jstor.org.notes: JSTOR is a digital library founded in 1995. Originally containing digitized back issues of academic journals, it now also includes books and primary sources, and current issues of journals. It provides full-text searches of almost 2,000 journals.  More than 8,000 institutions in more than 160 countries have access to JSTOR; most access is by subscription, but some older public-domain content is freely available to anyone.  (Wikipedia)

livescience.com.name: Live Science
livescience.com.notes: Live Science covers scientific breakthroughs, research ventures and odd facts from around the world in an online news magazine format.

howstuffworks.com.name: HowStuffWorks
howstuffworks.com.notes: HowStuffWorks is an American commercial educational website founded by Marshall Brain to provide its target audience an insight into the way many things work. The site uses various media to explain complex concepts, terminology, and mechanisms—including photographs, diagrams, videos, animations, and articles (Wikipedia).

mayoclinic.org.name: Mayo Clinic
mayoclinic.org.notes: Mayo Clinic is a nonprofit medical practice and medical research group based in Rochester, Minnesota.  It is a highly respected clinical medicine organization and also is a good resource for general health information.

medicalxpress.com.name: MedicalXPress
medicalxpress.com.notes: Medical Xpress is a health and medical news source which also publishes articles about the recent development in the health care industry and research in the field of medical science. The website is owned by Phys.org, which is a science, technology and research news website (Wikipedia).

technologyreview.com.name: MIT Technology Review
technologyreview.com.notes: MIT Technology Review is a magazine published by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

nasa.gov.name: NASA
nasa.gov.notes: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) is an independent agency of the executive branch of the United States federal government responsible for the civilian space program as well as aeronautics and aerospace research (Wikipedia).

ncse.com.name: National Center for Science Education (NCSE)
ncse.com.notes: The National Center for Science Education (NCSE) is a non-profit organization based in Oakland, California affiliated with the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The National Center for Science Education (NCSE) is a not-for-profit, membership organization whose stated mission is to educate the press and the public on the scientific and educational aspects of controversies surrounding the teaching of evolution and climate change, and to provide information and resources to schools, parents, and other citizens working to keep those topics in public school science education (Wikipedia).

nationalgeographic.com.name: National Geographic
nationalgeographic.com.notes: National Geographic, is the official magazine of the National Geographic Society. It has been published continuously since its first issue in 1888. It primarily contains articles about geography, history, and world culture.  On September 9, 2015, the National Geographic Society announced a deal with 21st Century Fox that would move the magazine to a new partnership, National Geographic Partners, controlled by 21st Century Fox (Wikipedia).

nationalacademyofsciences.org.name: National Academy of Sciences (NAS)
nationalacademyofsciences.org.notes: The National Academy of Sciences (NAS) is an United States nonprofit, non-governmental organization. The National Academy of Sciences is part of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, along with the National Academy of Engineering (NAE), the National Academy of Medicine, and the National Research Council (Wikipedia).

nih.gov.name: National Institutes of Health (NIH)
nih.gov.notes: The National Institutes of Health (NIH) is a biomedical research facility primarily located in Bethesda, Maryland. An agency of the United States Department of Health and Human Services, it is the primary agency of the United States government responsible for biomedical and health-related research. The NIH comprises 27 separate institutes and centers that conduct research in different disciplines of biomedical science.

nature.com.name: Nature
nature.com.notes: Nature is a British interdisciplinary scientific journal, first published on 4 November 1869. It was ranked the world’s most cited scientific journal by the Science Edition of the 2010 Journal Citation Reports, is ascribed an impact factor of approximately 38.1, and is widely regarded as one of the few remaining academic journals that publishes original research across a wide range of scientific fields.  (Wikipedia)

nautil.us.name: Nautilus Magazine
nautil.us.notes: Nautilus is an online and print science magazine. In 2014, the magazine won a Webby Award for best science website and was nominated for two others; and had two stories selected to be included in 2014 edition of The Best American Science and Nature Writing.  (Wikipedia)

neurosciencenews.com.name: Neuroscience News
neurosciencenews.com.notes: News and research on the topic Neuroscience.

newscientist.com.name: New Scientist
newscientist.com.notes: New Scientist is a UK-based weekly English-language international science magazine, founded in 1956. Since 1996 it has run a website (Wikipedia).

phys.org.name: Phys.org
phys.org.notes: Phys.org is a science, research and technology news website specializing in the hard science subjects of physics, space and earth science, biology, chemistry, electronics, nanotechnology and technology in general. The site also publishes daily reports, blogs and exclusive comprehensive articles on new peer reviewed scientific papers (Wikipedia).

ispp.org.name: Political Psychology Journal
ispp.org.notes: Political Psychology is a peer-reviewed academic journal published bimonthly by Wiley-Blackwell on behalf of the International Society of Political Psychology. The journal of the International Society of Political Psychology is dedicated to the analysis of the interrelationships between psychological and political processes. International contributors draw on a diverse range of sources, including cognitive psychology, political science, economics, history, international relations, philosophy, political theory, sociology, and social and clinical psychology. According to the Journal Citation Reports, the journal has a 2014 impact factor of 2.384, ranking it 8th out of 161 journals in the category “Political Science” and 12th out of 62 journals in the category “Psychology Social (Wikipedia).”

popularmechanics.com.name: Popular Mechanics
popularmechanics.com.notes: Popular Mechanics is a classic magazine of popular technology. First published January 11, 1902.

popsci.com.name: Popular Science
popsci.com.notes: Popular Science is an American bi-monthly magazine carrying popular science content, which refers to articles for the general reader on science and technology subjects. Popular Science has won over 58 awards, including the American Society of Magazine Editors awards for its journalistic excellence in both 2003 (for General Excellence) and 2004 (for Best Magazine Section). With roots beginning in 1872, PopSci has been translated into over 30 languages and is distributed to at least 45 countries (Wikipedia).

pnas.org.name: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (PNAS)
pnas.org.notes: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (PNAS) is the official scientific journal of the National Academy of Sciences, published since 1915. With broad coverage, spanning the biological, physical, and social sciences, the journal publishes “original research of exceptional importance”, alongside scientific reviews, commentaries, and letters. In 1999–2009, the last period for which data are available, PNAS was the second most cited journal across all fields of science (Wikipedia).

psychologytoday.com.name: Psychology Today
psychologytoday.com.notes: Psychology Today is a magazine published every two months in the United States.  Founded in 1967 by Nicolas Charney, Ph.D, its intent is to make psychology literature more accessible to the general public. The magazine focuses on behavior and covers a range of topics including psychology, neuroscience, relationships, sexuality, parenting, health (including from the perspectives of alternative medicine), work, and the psychological aspects of current affairs (Wikipedia).

psypost.org.name: Psypost
psypost.org.notes: PsyPost is a psychology and neuroscience news website dedicated to reporting the latest research on human behavior, cognition, and society. Our mission is to spread information about social science and neuroscience research (Psypost).

ncbi.nlm.nih.gov.name: PubMed
ncbi.nlm.nih.gov.notes: PubMed comprises more than 26 million citations for biomedical literature from MEDLINE, life science journals, and online books.

quackwatch.org.name: Quackwatch
quackwatch.org.notes: Exposes medical quackery and pseudoscience.  A great learning resource for detecting quackery.

realclearscience.com.name: Real Clear Science
realclearscience.com.notes: Real Clear Science is a portal to science news and opinion from around the globe. In addition to daily curated aggregation of news articles, university press releases and videos they also produce original content.  Since Real Clear Science draws articles from a variety of sources, these sources must also be checked.

redorbit.com.name: RedOrbit
redorbit.com.notes: A website that publishes science, technology and health news.

retractionwatch.com.name: Retraction Watch
retractionwatch.com.notes: Retraction Watch is a blog that reports on retractions of scientific papers. The blog was launched in August 2010 and is produced by science writers Ivan Oransky (Vice President and Global Editorial Director of MedPage Today) and Adam Marcus (editor of Gastroenterology & Endoscopy News). (Wikipedia)

scienceblogs.com.name: ScienceBlogs
scienceblogs.com.notes: ScienceBlogs is an invitation-only blog network and virtual community. It was created by Seed Media Group in 2006 to enhance the public understanding of science. Each blog has its own theme, specialty, and author(s) and is not subject to editorial control. Authors include active scientists working in industry, universities and medical schools as well as college professors, physicians, professional writers, graduate students, and post-docs (Wikipedia).

scicentral.com.name: SciCentral
scicentral.com.notes: SciCentral is a science news website that pulls content from legitimate sources.

factcheck.org/scicheck.name: SciCheck
factcheck.org/scicheck.notes: FactCheck.org’s SciCheck feature focuses exclusively on false and misleading scientific claims that are made by partisans to influence public policy. It was launched in January 2015 with a grant from the Stanton Foundation.

sciencebasedmedicine.org.name: Science Based Medicine
sciencebasedmedicine.org.notes: Science-Based Medicine is dedicated to evaluating medical treatments and products of interest to the public in a scientific light, and promoting the highest standards and traditions of science in health care.

sciencedaily.com.name: Science Daily
sciencedaily.com.notes: Science Daily is an American news website for topical science articles. It features articles on a wide variety of science topics including: astronomy, exoplanets, computer science, nanotechnology, medicine, psychology,sociology, anthropology, biology, geology, climate, space, physics, mathematics, chemistry, archaeology, paleontology, and others.  The articles are selected from news releases submitted by universities and other research institutions. (Wikipedia)

sciencedirect.com.name: ScienceDirect
sciencedirect.com.notes: ScienceDirect is a website which provides subscription-based access to a large database of scientific and medical research. It hosts over 12 million pieces of content from 3,500 academic journals and 34,000 e-books. (Wikipedia)

sciencemag.org.name: Science Magazine
sciencemag.org.notes: Science, also widely referred to as Science Magazine, is the peer-reviewed academic journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and one of the world’s top academic journals. (Wikipedia)

scientificamerican.com.name: Scientific American
scientificamerican.com.notes: Scientific American is an American popular science magazine. Many famous scientists, including Albert Einstein, have contributed articles in the past 170 years. It is the oldest continuously published monthly magazine in the United States. (Wikipedia)

skepticink.com.name: Skeptic Ink
skepticink.com.notes: Skeptic Ink is an independent outlet for scientific skepticism discourse. they are a diverse cast of writers, academics, philosophers, activists, and professionals writing on a broad range of topics but with concentrations in secularism and religion, philosophy, social justice, and social sciences. This source has low bias and high sourcing.

skeptic.com.name: Skeptic Magazine
skeptic.com.notes: Skeptic, colloquially known as Skeptic magazine, is a quarterly science education and science advocacy magazine published internationally by The Skeptics Society, a nonprofit organization devoted to promoting scientific skepticism and resisting the spread of pseudoscience, superstition, and irrational beliefs (Wikipedia).

skepdic.com.name: The Skeptic’s Dictionary
skepdic.com.notes: The Skeptic’s Dictionary provides definitions, arguments, and essays on subjects such as the supernatural, occult, paranormal, and pseudoscientific.

csicop.org/si.name: Skeptical Inquirer
csicop.org/si.notes: Skeptical Inquirer is a bimonthly American magazine published by the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI) with the subtitle: The Magazine for Science and Reason.

skepticalscience.com.name: Skeptical Science
skepticalscience.com.notes: Skeptical Science is a climate science blog and information resource created in 2007 by Australian blogger and author John Cook. In addition to publishing articles on current events relating to climate science and climate policy, the site maintains a large database of articles analyzing the merit of arguments commonly put forth by those involved in the global warming controversy who oppose the mainstream scientific opinion on climate change (Wikipedia).  Strictly adheres to the scientific consensus on climate change and sources to credible scientific studies.

skeptoid.com.name: Skeptoid
skeptoid.com.notes: Skeptoid is a podcast and website run by Brian Dunning who also contributes to SkepticBlog. Skeptoid is a myth, urban myth, and pseudo-science debunking site. It is very thorough and fair in its assessments. They present the myth, etc, then follow up with the actual science or facts regarding the issue. (D. Kelley)

skyandtelescope.com.name: Sky and Telescope
skyandtelescope.com.notes: Sky & Telescope (S&T) is a monthly American magazine covering all aspects of amateur astronomy.

smithsonianmag.com.name: Smithsonian Magazine
smithsonianmag.com.notes: Smithsonian is the official journal published by the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C. The first issue was published in 1970.  Smithsonian magazine provides in-depth analysis of varied topics within a diverse range of scientific areas. (Wikipedia)

space.com.name: Space.com
space.com.notes: Space.com is a space and astronomy news website. Its stories are often syndicated to other media outlets.

techxplore.com.name: TechXplore
techxplore.com.notes: Tech Xplore, is a part of the Phys.org Network. It covers the latest in engineering, electronics, and tech.

understandrealitythroughscience.blogspot.name: Understand Reality Through Science
understandrealitythroughscience.blogspot.notes: Understand Reality Through Science is the personal blog of Author Tom Rafferty, who wrote the book “Making Stuff Up is Unwise: An Introduction to Reason, Skepticism and Science.” The blog writes original content as well as curated and hand selected science news from a diverse range of scientific topics.  They specialize in debunking pseudoscience and myth.

ucsusa.org.name: Union of Concerned Scientists
ucsusa.org.notes: The Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS) is a nonprofit science advocacy organization based in the United States.  While the UCS is generally a good scientific source they do move slightly against the consensus on GMO, solar and a few other issues.  They have been criticized for having a political/financial bias.  Despite that, the good outweighs the bad with this source and we consider them Pro-Science.

webmd.com.name: WebMD
webmd.com.notes: WebMD is an American corporation known primarily as an online publisher of news and information pertaining to human health and well-being.  Although WebMD is typically scientifically sound it has been criticized for promoting drugs that are unnecessary by their pharmaceutical sponsors.

whatstheharm.net.name: What’s the Harm
whatstheharm.net.notes: A website that looks at pseudoscience and the damage it causes to both health and economy.

who.int.name: World Health Organization (WHO)
who.int.notes: The World Health Organization is a specialized agency of the United Nations that is concerned with international public health. It was established on 7 April 1948, headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland. (Wikipedia)  The World Health Organization has position papers on virtually every health issue and its opinion is the consensus of the medical experts around the world.

21stcenturywire.com.name: 21st Century Wire
21stcenturywire.com.notes: 21st Century Wire is a conspiracy site that focuses on politics.  Considers climate change a myth and promotes a variety of other conspiracies that focus on war. 21st Century Wire does produce legitimate news among the conspiracies.

369news.net.name: 369News
369news.net.notes: 369News promotes conspiracy theories and endorses pseudoscience.  Has a fascination with the Illuminati and miracle natural cures for cancer. Does report legitimate news also.

asheepnomore.net.name: A Sheep No More
asheepnomore.net.notes: Completely insane conspiracy stories that seem like satire.  Everything from the New World Order, Aliens and Chemtrails.  This one has it all.

latitudes.org.name: ACN Latitudes
latitudes.org.notes: The Association for Comprehensive Neurotherapy is an integrative therapy and medical quackery website.

activistpost.com.name: Activist Post
activistpost.com.notes: Activist Post promotes typical conspiracy theories and pseudoscience.

awdnews.com.name: AWD News
awdnews.com.notes: AWD News mostly publishes right wing conspiracies with a preoccupation for world war. Does occasionally publish credible news.

ageofautism.com.name: Age of Autism
ageofautism.com.notes: Promotes Autism pseudoscience and anti-vaccines while promoting alternative medicine. This is not a credible science source.

althealthworks.com.name: AltHealth Works
althealthworks.com.notes: Focuses on health, agriculture and nutrition pseudoscience and conspiracies.  Anti-vaccines and GMO.

americanfreepress.net.name: American Free Press
americanfreepress.net.notes: Willis Carto, one of America’s most influential political racial theorists known for his promotion of antisemitic conspiracy theories and Holocaust denial, was one of its founders. The newspaper describes itself as “maverick, independent grass-roots media” and proclaims a “populist and nationalist” political orientation.  Basically this website promotes racism and conspiracy theories regarding race.

americanintelligencereport.com.name: American Intelligence Report
americanintelligencereport.com.notes: American Intelligence Report is the blog/website of Kristan T. Harris who also has a radio show. The website features a variety of right wing conspiracies ranging from Fema Camps to the Illuminati and many more. Occasionally publishes real news.

anonews.co.name: Anonymous
anonews.co.notes: Not to be confused with We Are Anonymous.  This source publishes only conspiracies and pseudoscience.

anotherdayintheempire.com.name: Another Day in the Empire
anotherdayintheempire.com.notes: Another Day in the Empire provides right wing conspiracies in between typical right wing biased articles. They do occasionally publish factual, sourced information.

answersingenesis.org.name: Answers in Genesis
answersingenesis.org.notes: Answers in Genesis (AiG), headed by Ken Ham, is a Christian apologetics ministry which pushes “creation science.”

awarenessact.com.name: Awareness Act
awarenessact.com.notes: Awareness Act is a classic conspiracy site that focuses on aliens and the New World Order.  They also have little regard for science.

blacklistednews.com.name: Blacklisted News
blacklistednews.com.notes: Blacklisted News publishes real news stories mixed with conspiracy theories and some pseudo-science.

centerforsecuritypolicy.org.name: Center for Security Policy
centerforsecuritypolicy.org.notes: The Center for Security Policy (CSP) is a Washington, D.C.-based national security think tank that has been widely accused of engaging in conspiracy theorizing by a range of individuals, media outlets and organizations. Its activities are focused on exposing and researching perceived jihadist threats to the United States.  The Southern Poverty Law Center has described it as “a conspiracy-oriented mouthpiece for the growing anti-Muslim movement in the United States.” (Wikipedia)

charismanews.com.name: Charisma News
charismanews.com.notes: An extreme christian right news source.  The website delves into conspiracy theories and publishes hatred toward LGBT and minorities.  This site promotes pseudoscience and some conspiracies.

christiantimesnewspaper.com.name: Christian Times Newspaper
christiantimesnewspaper.com.notes: Extreme right wing conservative bias.  Routinely publishes ridiculous conspiracy theories.  If you are looking for facts this is the wrong place.

climatedepot.com.name: Climate Depot
climatedepot.com.notes: ClimateDepot.com is the website of Committee for a Constructive Tomorrow employee Marc Morano, a conservative global warming denier who previously served as environmental communications director for a vocal political denier of climate change, Republican Sen. James Inhofe (Sourcewatch).

coasttocoastam.com.name: Coast to Coast AM
coasttocoastam.com.notes: A media phenomenon, Coast to Coast AM deals with UFOs, strange occurrences, life after death, and other unexplained (and often inexplicable) phenomena. Coast to Coast AM is overnight talk radio with a large following.

collectivelyconscious.net.name: Collectively Conscious
collectivelyconscious.net.notes: Collectively Conscious is your one stop for everything conspiracy and pseudoscience. Aliens, world war 3, new world order, miracle cures, etc.  It has them all.

collective-evolution.com.name: Collective-Evolution
collective-evolution.com.notes: Collective-Evolution is a woo-mongering clickbait website. They label themselves as an alternative news source that seeks to expand their way of “thinking” to create “big change” on the planet (RationalWiki). Total Junk Science.

consciouslifenews.com.name: Conscious Life News
consciouslifenews.com.notes: Conscious Life News is a news and opinion website that promotes junk pseudoscience and miracle cures. They do publish some legitimate tech news and other scientifically grounded information, but the pseudoscience outweighs it.

conspiracyplanet.com.name: Conspiracy Planet
conspiracyplanet.com.notes: The name says it all.  Over the top conspiracies. 9/11, UFOs, new world order and several you probably never heard before.

countdowntozerotime.com.name: Countdown to Zerotime
countdowntozerotime.com.notes: A combination of crazy conspiracy and pseudoscience. This source may be the most overt conspiracy site on the internet.

countercurrentnews.com.name: Counter Current News
countercurrentnews.com.notes: Counter Current News is a left biased online news and opinion website that publishes real news mixed with conspiracies and pseudoscience.

counterpsyops.com.name: CounterPsyOps
counterpsyops.com.notes: Conspiracy theories heavily focused on Israel and Iran.

csglobe.com.name: CS Globe
csglobe.com.notes: CS Globe is a news and opinion website that mostly publishes conspiracy theories and pseudoscience stories.

dailyoccupation.com.name: Daily Occupation
dailyoccupation.com.notes: Dabbles in conspiracy theories, but is over the top with Pseudoscience quackery.

dailystar.co.uk.name: Daily Star UK
dailystar.co.uk.notes: The Daily Star is a UK based tabloid style newspaper.  They use over sensationalized headlines for most stories.  This source does publish legitimate news, however, it also posts conspiracies and pseudoscience articles.

davidicke.com.name: David Icke
davidicke.com.notes: David Icke is an English writer and public speaker. A former footballer and sports broadcaster, Icke has made his name since the 1990s as a professional conspiracy theorist, calling himself a “full time investigator into who and what is really controlling the world (Wikipedia).” There are simply too many instances to list that David Icke is an over-the-top conspiracy theorist, but this is the one that he is most famous for: Icke believes many public figures are reptilian humanoids and paedophiles. Mr. Icke is either the greatest con artist in history having amassed over 20 million dollars on books and speeches or he is certifiably insane.

davidwolfe.com.name: David Wolfe
davidwolfe.com.notes: David “Avocado” Wolfe is a raw foodist, promoter of alternative medicine, conspiracy theorist, entrepreneur, and spokesman for the NutriBullet.  Complete nutritional quackery.

dataasylum.com.name: Data Asylum
dataasylum.com.notes: Chemtrails and other conspiracies are at Data Asylum.

disclose.tv.name: Disclose TV
disclose.tv.notes: Ridiculous unsubstantiated conspiracies about aliens, the new world order and government. Even Alex Jones wouldn’t believe these stories.

discovery.org.name: Discovery Institute
discovery.org.notes: The Discovery Institute is a non-profit Christian public policy think tank based in Seattle, Washington, best known for its advocacy of the pseudoscientific principle of intelligent design.

ecowatch.com.name: Ecowatch
ecowatch.com.notes: Environmental activist group.  Has many legitimate articles, but dabbles in pseudoscience on certain scientific issues.

educate-yourself.org.name: Educate Yourself
educate-yourself.org.notes: Focuses on alternative medicine and other pseudosciences.  Loves conspiracy theories as well.

endtimeheadlines.org.name: End Time Headlines
endtimeheadlines.org.notes: End Time Headlines is a website that publishes news stories related to the biblical prophecy of End Times. Promotes conspiracies such as the new world order and some scientific quackery.

everynewshere.com.name: Every News Here
everynewshere.com.notes: Every News Here is an extreme right wing news and opinion site.  They consistently publish conspiracies and they have a science news page that is filled with pseudoscience.

evolutionnews.org.name: Evolution News and Views
evolutionnews.org.notes: Evolution News and Views is a part of The Discovery Institute which is a non-profit Christian public policy think tank based in Seattle, Washington, best known for its advocacy of the pseudoscientific principle of intelligent design.

familysurvivalheadlines.com.name: Family Survival Headlines
familysurvivalheadlines.com.notes: Family Survival Headlines is a blog that publishes stories about imminent disasters and how to survive them. Most stories comes from the biblical conspiracy website End Time News. This source is borderline Tin Foil Hat.

foodbabe.com.name: Food Babe
foodbabe.com.notes: Vani Deva Hari, also known on her blog as the Food Babe, is an American author, activist, and affiliate marketer known for her criticism of the food industry.  Hari’s ideas on food safety have been criticized by scientists as pseudoscience and chemophobia, and others have drawn attention to her apparent financial interest through promotion and marketing of natural foods (

fromthetrenchesworldreport.com.name: From the Trenches World Report
fromthetrenchesworldreport.com.notes: From the Trenches produces right wing biased reporting that features conspiracies and pseudoscience.

globalresearch.ca.name: Global Research
globalresearch.ca.notes: Publishes many unsubstantiated conspiracies. While some of Global Research’s articles discuss legitimate humanitarian concerns, its view of science, economics, and geopolitics is conspiracist.

globalskywatch.com.name: Global Skywatch
globalskywatch.com.notes: Global Skywatch is dedicated to bringing you the latest news regarding chemtrails.

govtslaves.info.name: Government Slaves
govtslaves.info.notes: Government conspiracy theories.  Fema Camps, Chemtrails, etc.

greenpeace.org.name: Greenpeace
greenpeace.org.notes: Left wing environmental activist group.  Strays from science on a few issues, such as GMO.

healtheternally.com.name: Health Eternally
healtheternally.com.notes: A pretty typical pseudoscience site that deals mostly with nutrition and alternative medicine.

healthimpactnews.com.name: Health Impact News
healthimpactnews.com.notes: Pure pseudoscience.  According to Web of Trust this site has been flagged for misleading claims, alternative and/or controversial medicine.  The site misleads people with quackery.

healthnutnews.com.name: Health Nut News
healthnutnews.com.notes: Health Nut News is founded and run by Erin Elizabeth.  The information on this site is flat out medical and nutritional quackery.  There is also a few conspiracy theories thrown in for good measure.  If you follow the advice on these pages you are putting yourself at risk.  The key word here is “Nut.”

alexanderhiggins.com.name: Higgins News Network
alexanderhiggins.com.notes: The Higgins News Network is a news and opinion website that promotes both conspiracy and pseudoscience. This source does publish valid news as well.

breakthrough.holylandnutrition.com.name: HL12
breakthrough.holylandnutrition.com.notes: I honestly am not sure how to report this. There is something about Atheist Scientists destroying the world and then the answer being hidden cures in the Bible.  Needless to say this is complete insanity.

humansarefree.com.name: Humans Are Free
humansarefree.com.notes: A combination of conspiracy and pseudoscience. Almost every article on this website is false.

illuminati-news.com.name: Illuminati News
illuminati-news.com.notes: No explanation needed.  100% conspiracies. UFOs, aliens, mind control, new world order is all here.

independentlivingnews.com.name: Independent Living News
independentlivingnews.com.notes: Independent Living News is a news and opinion site about health, food and self reliance.  This source has a right wing political bias that advocates pseudoscience and some conspiracies.

infiniteunknown.net.name: Infinite Unknown
infiniteunknown.net.notes: Infinite Unknown is a right wing biased news and opinion website that promotes conspiracies and pseudoscience.

infowars.com.name: Infowars-Alex Jones
infowars.com.notes: A radio program and website run by the legendary conspiracy theorist Alex Jones.  Non-stop over the top conspiracies.  This is the gold standard for Tin-Foil Hat conspiracies.

icr.org.name: Institute for Creation Research (ICR)
icr.org.notes: The Institute for Creation Research (ICR) is a young-Earth creationist faux-research organization that produces voluminous quote mines and logical fallacies in pursuit of debunking evolution and an old earth (RationalWiki).

responsibletechnology.org.name: Institute for Responsible Technology
responsibletechnology.org.notes: Blatantly anti-science and pro-pseudoscience.  Reject the science of GMO’s and others with a clear consensus.

investmentwatchblog.com.name: Investment Watch Blog
investmentwatchblog.com.notes: Investment Watch Blog does publish real news, however they also publish conspiracy news and some scientifically questionable articles.  This source is not that bad, but a fact check is advised when reading their information.  This source tends to have a right wing bias.

jewsnews.co.il.name: Jews News
jewsnews.co.il.notes: Jews News is a news and opinion site from Israel with over 1 million Facebook likes.  Unfortunately, this source publishes ultra-right wing anti-Muslim propaganda and pushes conspiracy and pseudoscience such as aliens and health quackery.

jonesreport.com.name: Jones Report
jonesreport.com.notes: This appears to be recycled news from the Alex Jones Radio Show and Infowars Website.  Needless to say it is Tin-Foil Hat crazy with conspiracy.

larouchepac.com.name: LaRouche PAC
larouchepac.com.notes: The LaRouche PAC is loosely based on the LaRouche movement which is a political and cultural network promoting Lyndon LaRouche and his ideas. The LaRouche movement used to be considered a left wing group. however since the 1970’s it has moved to the right and is currently anti-climate change calling support of it Green Facism. It also promotes fear of world war 3 through videos and questionable news. The LaRouche movement is seen as a fringe political cult. In the summer of 2009, LaRouche followers came under criticism from both Democrats and Republicans for comparing President Barack Obama to Hitler. Media figures as politically diverse as Rush Limbaugh and Jon Stewart criticized the comparison (Wikipedia).

libertyvideos.org.name: Liberty Videos
libertyvideos.org.notes: Liberty Videos posts conspiracy videos about 9/11 and other popular conspiracies.

liveaction.org.name: Live Action
liveaction.org.notes: Live Action is an American anti-abortion non-profit organization founded by in 2003 by then 15 year-old Lila Rose. Live Action is known for its undercover video sting operations on Planned Parenthood clinics. Pro-choice advocates have accused them of video editing.

livingresistance.com.name: Living Resistance
livingresistance.com.notes: Living Resistance is a news and opinion website that promotes conspiracy and pseudoscience.  The site does publish some factual stories, so it can be deceiving.  Overall, each story must be checked for accuracy on this website.

livingwhole.org.name: Living Whole
livingwhole.org.notes: Living Whole is a blog dedicated to health, parenting, spirituality and nutritional quackery. Has a very strong anti-vaccine bias.

mercola.com.name: Mercola
mercola.com.notes: Joseph Michael Mercola is an alternative medicine proponent, osteopathic physician, and web entrepreneur, who markets a variety of controversial dietary supplements and medical devices through his website, Mercola.com. Mercola and colleagues advocate a number of unproven alternative health notions including homeopathy, while promoting anti-vaccine positions (Wikipedia).

modernalternativemama.com.name: Modern Alternative Mama
